Reviews:
Telltale Games'i Sam & Max serisi (benim için) başta olmak üzere sinematik adventure oyunları ile tanıyoruz. Hector serisi ilk işlerinden biri. Karşımızda Day Of The Tentacle stili karikatür görseller ve ağır kara mizah içeren bir point & click var. Oyun toplamda üç bölümden oluşuyor ve henüz ilkini tamamlamış durumdayım. Bilmecelerin çoğu absürd ama "yuh artık" dedirtecek kadar saçma değil. Bu nedenle oyunda pek takılmıyorsunuz. İki bilmece hariç. Onlarla ilgili maalesef oyun pek bir ipucu vermiyor (ya da belki de ben gözden kaçırmışımdır). Oyundaki ağır kara mizah haricinde adventure oyuncularının hoşlanmayabileceğini düşündüğüm bir şey yok. O da kişiden kişiye değişecek bir durum tabii ki. Kendi adıma ben bu tip mizahı sevdiğim için oyundan keyif aldım. Günümüzdeki "woke" atmosferde bu tip bir oyun yapmak ne kadar kolay olurdu onu bilemiyorum. Aşırı politik doğrucu değilseniz ve adventure seviyorsanız indirimdeyken mutlaka deneyin. | Probably as close to a yes as a not recommended can be but ultimately its a bit date, very simple point and click "puzzle" game, that is alright for a cheap laugh (and on sale this is cheap for what amounts to about 6 hours play time).

If you like the trailers, then maybe get it but it does feel like time and money spend better else where, I only picked it up because I played the first 2 on ipad many moons ago and wanted to play the end myself. Its not like theres much of a series to come to invest your time in this IP anyway. | Don´t know what I expected, but this wasn´t it. Still I enjoyed it tho. 7.1-10 | Feels like one of those games you pulled out of a pc gamer demo cd in the 90s and thought "the fuck is this shit".
cleaned_review: Sam & Max's Sam & Max game is a classic adventure game, a combination of three parts: a kara mizah, a saxophone, and a point & click.

Reviews:
Hector'un ikinci bölümü ilkinden her anlamda daha iyi. Daha fazla lokasyon, daha fazla (ve daha iyi) bilmece, daha fazla karakter, oyunun bir bölümünde karakterler arası geçiş imkanı ve daha da aşırıya kaçan kara mizah dozu. Oyun İngiltere'de geçtiğinden yapılan esprileri anlamak için biraz İngiliz mizahına ve stereotiplerine hakim olmak gerekiyor. Oyun boyunca İskoçlar, İrlandalılar ve hatta Slovaklar Hector'un aşağılamalarından nasiplerini alıyorlar. Bunlara kilolu kadınları, yaşlıları ve daha başkalarını da eklemek gerekir. Önceki bölüm için yazdığım incelemede de belirttiğim üzere, Hector günümüzün "woke" ikliminde yapılması mümkün olmayan bir oyun. Politik doğrucu olmayan kaba İngiliz mizahını ve Sam & Max / Day Of The Tentacle stili absürd Point & Click seviyorsanız mutlaka şans verin. | Unlike the first one, this game didn´t deliver. the help menue was anoying to use and the game just wasn´t as good as the first part. 5-10 | Kul uppföljare med klureri och gåtor.

Grovt språk och humor som alltid. | Not even alcohol makes this game good.

Game Name: Hector: Badge of Carnage - Full Series
Reviews:
Hector'un en iyi bölümü. Özet geçmek gerekirse Sam & Max / Day Of The Tentactle tarzı absürd, kara mizah içerikli Point & Click Adventure. En önemli iki fark ise oyunun İngiltere'nin ücra bir yerlerinde geçmesi ve aşırı yüksek kara mizah dozu. Eğer hafiften mide bulandırıcı, zalim, politik doğruculuğa ters mizah seviyorsanız oyunda muhtemelen bol bol gülecekseniz. Sevmiyorsanız da bence uzak dursanız daha iyi olur. Serinin en uzun ve en iyi bölümü, tabiri caizse yağ gibi aktı gitti. | -геймдизайн. будет русский - гляну.
-сюжет. хз, лопочат чо та на басурманском.
~графика. рисовка забавная. | They saved the best for last. Unlike the second episode you didn´t need the help butten in order to know what it is you´re supposed to be doing. I also liked the fact that the characters from previous episodes reappeard tn this one. 7.5-10 | Most positive thing about the third game is that I'm finally done with the series.

Étant un grand fan de Sam & Max Hit the Road sorti en 1993, j'ai ressenti une immense joie en apprenant l'existence du projet de Telltale Games au milieu des années 2000.
Le premier épisode ne m'a pas déçu : on y retrouve l'humour si particulier du duo, et le passage des gros pixels à la 3D fonctionne à merveille.

J'ai rejoué plusieurs fois la première saison, et je ne m'en lasse pas. (Le temps de jeu indiqué sur Steam ne reflète pas mon véritable temps passé, car je l'avais initialement acheté en version physique directement sur le site de Telltale Games.)

Bien que cette version ne soit plus disponible sur le Store, vous pouvez désormais acheter le remake Sam & Max Save the World, sorti en 2020. Ce remake regroupe les six épisodes de la première saison, avec des graphismes améliorés.

Si vous aimez les point & click dans le style de LucasArts et l'humour décalé, n'hésitez pas une seconde : foncez !
cleaned_review: Sam & Max Hit the Road is a slick, slick, and fun game that's sure to please fans of the series.

Reviews: good game

Game Name: Sam & Max 103: The Mole, the Mob and the Meatball
Reviews:
[h1]Ryan George Style Pitch Meeting (with Mafia Guest Stars)[/h1]

Publisher: So, you have a wild mafia-themed point-and-click adventure game for me?

Game Designer: Yes, sir, I do! It's called Sam & Max: The Mole, the Mob, and the Meatball. Sam and Max, the freelance police, get caught up in a ridiculous mafia plot, trying to find a mole while dealing with a missing meatball sandwich. But oh, it’s much bigger than that. They end up infiltrating the Toy Mafia, causing chaos everywhere they go!

Publisher: A meatball sandwich is the focus of this mafia plot?

Game Designer: Oh, absolutely. It’s the most important thing in the whole episode! Someone stole the famous sandwich from the casino, and Sam and Max need to track it down—or else.

Publisher: Right. So, there’s a missing sandwich, and that somehow involves the mafia?

Game Designer: You bet! But there’s also so much more going on. Sam and Max are trying to track down this mole in the Toy Mafia by doing jobs for them. Like, killing Sybil, faking her death, and getting hypnotic bears into Bosco’s store. But—plot twist—they also have to track down this sandwich, and it's critical to the whole mission.

Publisher: Right, right. So there’s a sandwich, a mafia, and a couple of freelancing cartoon cops?

Game Designer: Exactly! And lots of crazy characters! You got Bosco, who’s paranoid about the Toy Mafia, and Leonard Steakcharmer, a casino cheater who’s cheating his way to 10 million casino tokens. Oh, and there’s a spy tool called “The Bug” that they use to eavesdrop on people.

Publisher: The Bug? How does that work?

Game Designer: Oh, you know, it’s just a device that records conversations and then replays them. It’s like a gadget out of a spy movie, but with a lot more cartoon nonsense.

Publisher: Okay, okay, I’m following. And these jobs for the mafia... What are they?

Game Designer: Well, they need to take out Sybil—but it’s not what you think—they fake her death using ketchup. And then there’s the whole situation with the hypnotic bears. They need to deliver them to Bosco’s store. The mafia’s a mess, and Sam and Max have to play both sides to survive!

Publisher: Hypnotic bears? Faking deaths with ketchup? I’m not sure this is what I imagined when you said “mafia game.”

Game Designer: Oh, but it works! The comedy is so over-the-top. Sam and Max don’t know what they’re doing half the time, which just makes everything funnier. They’re the worst mafia henchmen, but they somehow still get the job done—barely.

Publisher: Okay, but how do they infiltrate the mafia?

Game Designer: Easy! They get into the mafia by doing jobs for them. They’re hired as assassins, then take on some ridiculous missions. And then, surprise, they get inducted into the mafia by completing all the tasks. But it’s not easy—no one trusts them. And then there’s the mole! The mole’s working for the mafia!

Publisher: The mole?

Game Designer: Yeah, Ted E. Bear! But guess what? He’s actually a mole-man! The twist is that he was sent by the police to infiltrate the mafia, but instead, he becomes the mafia boss.

Publisher: So the mole infiltrates the mafia, becomes the mafia boss, and then tries to hypnotize Sam and Max?

Game Designer: Exactly! And they’re immune to his hypnosis, but they fake Max’s death to trick him anyway. Classic Sam & Max!

Publisher: Alright, that’s wild. But what happens at the end?

Game Designer: Oh, it’s huge! They defeat Ted E. Bear, blow up the toy factory, and finally get the mole—but the meatball sandwich is still gone. It’s a real cliffhanger.

Publisher: Wait, wait. You never find the meatball sandwich?

Game Designer: Nope! It’s a running mystery. Sam and Max just leave it as this unresolved joke.

Publisher: Oh, I like that. But listen, I gotta ask: Is there anything else I should know about the game? Anything extra?

Game Designer: Well, yeah! There’s the Toy Mafia’s headquarters, a giant toy factory, and some absolutely absurd interactions. Oh, and Sam and Max might blow up the toy factory by the end of it! It’s like... it’s like if you took a mafia film, added in cartoons, a sandwich, and, like, a lot of chaos.

Publisher: Okay, I’m in. It’s ridiculous enough to work. So, what’s next?

Game Designer: Well, I’m thinking merchandising, right? We make the meatball sandwich a real item. I mean, who wouldn’t want that?!

Publisher: You’re right. I’m sold.

[Suddenly, the door bursts open, and Tony Soprano, Fat Tony, and Don Corleone enter.]

Tony Soprano: Hey, what’s all this about a meatball sandwich?

Fat Tony: I’m listenin’... and I gotta say, I like what you’re doin’. But we gotta talk about this whole mafia thing. You got the right people here, you know?

Don Corleone: You want to make them an offer they can’t refuse, eh?

Game Designer: Uh, what are you doing here?!

Publisher: Oh no, not this again.

Tony Soprano: You’re gonna need some muscle for that meatball sandwich, huh? We can help with that.

Fat Tony: Yeah, we got people who handle sandwiches. People who don’t just let them go missing.

Don Corleone: I’ll make them an offer... a sandwich offer. They won’t be able to refuse.

Publisher: Guys, this is a game pitch, not a mob deal!

Game Designer: Yeah! I’m just trying to get the game greenlit here!

Tony Soprano: Listen, listen. We’re here to talk sandwiches and business. You need our help, capisce?

Fat Tony: Maybe throw in a little meatball connection, and we can talk. Business is business, after all.

Don Corleone: You should have come to us sooner, but we’ll take care of it.

Publisher: Oh, for the love of... Fine, fine! Let’s just make this work!
cleaned_review: The Bug is a spy tool that records conversations and replays them.

Game Name: Sam & Max 104: Abe Lincoln Must Die!
Reviews:
Very fun and funny game. It's kinda dated but in a really charming way, so it holds up. All around great game! | What would you do if you'd receive an assignment where you'd have to deal directly with the President of the United States of America? First of all, thank the Lord that this is only a game, so you may at least get a chance. And while you're at it, you'd might as well enjoy this opportunity as much as you can

Without the intention of getting into many details, Max will have to run as a candidate for President against Abraham Lincoln. You never know what to expect from the side characters, even though you already know that it's going to be something unusual. This time, Sybil decided to start a career as a dating service consultant and Bosco is disguised as a Russian, and keeps ramping out his prices through the roof and beyond. The Soda Poppers are now for whatever reason the governors of Dakota and want to find a solution to settle down their differences

The humor on this one isn't all over the place, even though there're some clever jokes that I thought that were really funny. As for the puzzles, I thought that some of them were a bit cryptic and I nearly decided to check on a walkthrough to see what I was supposed to do, but luckily I've managed to figure out what I had to do

Overall, the episode keeps getting as crazy as possible and I can't wait to see how's the next one going to be | Légèrement plus subtil, il faudra faire plusieurs aller-retours entre les zones pour en arriver à bout. J'ai un peu tourné en rond avant de trouver certaines choses. | Sam & Max follows a formula, sure, but sitcom predictability is proving to be this series' secret strength -- it's rare to see a game conjure up such strong narrative continuity and familiarity in such short a time span. In Telltale's hands, recycled assets take on the aspect of recurring joys. | 1. Проснуться
2. Поиграть в дартс
3. Убить президента
4. Стать президентом
5. Начать ГЕНЕЗИС
cleaned_review: 1. Play 2. Run 3. Get a job

Reviews:
[h1]Mr. T's "Reali-T" Review of Reality 2.0[/h1]

[Scene: Mr. T is sitting in his signature gold chains, his muscular arms crossed, in a chair that looks way too small for him. He looks straight at the camera. The camera zooms in on his serious face.]

Mr. T:
Ain’t no time for no games, fool! But you know what? I got somethin’ that I gotta talk about. Reality 2.0. Yeah, that’s right, I’m gonna break it down for you, ‘cause when it comes to reality, there’s only one real "Reali-T" — and that’s me! Mr. T. So buckle up, I’m about to give you a reality check, you hear me?

[The camera switches to a close-up of Mr. T holding up the Reality 2.0 game box. He squints at it like it’s the most confusing thing he’s ever seen.]

Mr. T:
Now, I ain’t no expert in these newfangled video games, but I’m about to check this out. You think you can mess with me? Well, guess what? This ain’t no virtual world. This is Reali-T, baby! So you better believe I’m gonna break this down, real loud and real clear, just like my chains when I walk. Let's go.

[Cut to the Reality 2.0 main menu screen. Mr. T is staring at it intently.]

Mr. T:
Wait a minute, hold up. This some kind of crazy sci-fi mess? They got me flying through space, and now I'm in some weird "Reality 2.0" world? I’m the star, fool! I should be the one running the show, not some funky VR goggles. You think you can hypnotize me with your little virtual world? Ha! Ain't gonna happen.

[On the screen, Sybil is seen in the game, getting hypnotized by the goggles. Mr. T's eyes narrow.]

Mr. T:
Look at this, man. Sybil's all up in this mess, getting hypnotized by them goggles. Fool, that’s what happens when you mess with a fake reality. You need some Reali-T like Mr. T! I don’t get hypnotized. I break chains, I break hearts, and I break games, baby. That’s how I roll.

[The camera cuts to a shot of Mr. T shaking his head as he continues playing. Sybil explains the premise of Reality 2.0, which draws Mr. T into the game.]

Mr. T:
Okay, okay, now I’m in. But listen to me, when I step into a game, I bring the Reali-T! This whole “Reality 2.0” thing? It’s cute. They got these little pop-up ads and some holograms, and everybody’s all like “Oh, wow, it’s so real!” Well, lemme tell you, if I wanted some real chaos, I’d just go out there and deal with real clowns. Not this digital nonsense.

[Mr. T’s character moves around the Reality 2.0 world, interacting with NPCs.]

Mr. T:
Hey, look at this. I’m talking to some goofy, holographic NPC. Man, I don’t need no virtual friends. I got the real deal. You hear me? I got Reali-T. I’m talking about real friends, real fights, and real gold chains, fool.

[He navigates the dialogue options in the game, which leads him to visit Bosco in the virtual world.]

Mr. T:
Oh, snap. Bosco’s in here? You know Bosco don’t know nothin’ about Reali-T. Look at him, sellin' me a billion-dollar snot rag. What’s this, Bosco? A virtual germ? Fool, I don’t need a virtual disease. I got Reali-T and the only thing I’m catchin’ is victory!

[Bosco hands over a handkerchief to Mr. T’s character in exchange for a ridiculous amount of virtual money.]

Mr. T:
You see this, fool? Bosco’s got this germ… and I gotta pay a billion dollars for it? Man, back in the day, I’d punch out a germ and still have enough for a gold chain.

[Mr. T takes a deep breath, staring at the screen like it’s the most ridiculous thing he’s ever seen.]

Mr. T:
You know, I gotta admit, this whole virtual world thing is getting on my nerves. You got people all hooked into these Reality 2.0 goggles like they’re a new kind of drug. You think you can trap Mr. T in a virtual world? You can’t even trap my real self in a phone booth, fool. This is reality, baby!

[The camera cuts to a segment where Mr. T is preparing to fight the main villain, "The Internet."]

Mr. T:
Alright, alright, now we got ourselves a real challenge. I’m about to fight The Internet? Oh, you think you can mess with me, The Internet? I’ve got 15 years of catching up on shows I don’t watch, I’ve got ten email accounts with nothing but spam, and I’ve got enough cat memes to break the World Wide Web! You wanna bring some “virtual” apocalypse? I’ll show you what happens when Mr. T goes full throttle, baby.

[The camera zooms in on Mr. T’s face as he clenches his fist.]

Mr. T:
Fool, you can’t defeat me. You think you can lock me in some digital space? Nah. I got the key to the real world. Let me tell you something. I am the only thing in here that’s real, and when I hit you with this handkerchief full of germs, you’re going down harder than my gold chains when I take ‘em off at the end of the day.

[The Internet, personified as a woman, starts monologuing, but Mr. T interrupts.]

Mr. T:
Ain’t nobody got time for your speeches, girl. This ain’t a TED Talk. This is Mr. T’s reality, and you’re about to get takedown-ed like a bad dial-up connection in 1998.

[As the battle intensifies, Shakespeare suddenly appears in the game world, holding a quill and scroll, appearing in front of Mr. T’s character.]

Shakespeare:
Hark! What light through yonder game breaks? It is the fool, and I do declare—

Mr. T:
Wait, wait—did you just say "fool"? Who you callin' a fool, Shakespeare? You don’t want none of this, you got yourself a quill and some poetry, but I’ve got chains and a bad attitude!

Shakespeare:
Nay, I call thee fool not as an insult, but as a reflection of thine ignorance to the way of games and virtual worlds!

Mr. T:
You know what? I pity the fool who thinks they can outwit me in a game, and it’s lookin’ like you’re that fool!

Shakespeare:
I pity thy fool! Forsooth, thy game is but a shadow! The only Reali-T that shall endure is the one that hath substance in the heart, not in pixels.

Mr. T:
Oh, snap! You got that right, fool. It’s all about the heart. And my heart? Well, it beats for Reali-T, and that means keeping it real. No more virtual nonsense.

[The game continues, but Mr. T now delivers a dramatic finishing blow to "The Internet."]

Mr. T:
See? That’s how you shut down a fake reality. Mr. T’s Reali-T—now that’s the only thing you need, Shakespeare, you hear me? No more tricks. No more fake worlds. Just gold chains, muscles, and the best of what’s real.

Shakespeare:
Thou art truly a man of action, Mr. T! Prithee, carry on! I leave thee to your chains, your glory, and your victory.

[Mr. T stands victorious, arms crossed, as Shakespeare fades into the virtual ether.]

Mr. T:
Alright, Shakespeare, you know what? You may have been right, fool. This was the final boss, and I handled it like a champion. I ain't no virtual hero. I’m the real deal. That’s Reali-T! And you can’t mess with the best when you got gold chains and the power of Reali-T on your side!

[Mr. T walks off camera as dramatic music swells, the camera zooms out, and the screen cuts to black.]

[End of Review.]

Game Name: Sam & Max 106: Bright Side of the Moon
Reviews:
[h1]Title: "Breaking Bad Crew vs. The Bright Side of the Moon"[/h1]

[Scene: A dimly lit RV, parked in the middle of the desert. The hum of the engine is the only sound. Inside, Walter White, clad in his iconic Heisenberg hat, sits in the driver’s seat, gripping the controller with a steady hand. Jesse Pinkman lounges on the couch, his eyes wide and eager. They're playing Sam & Max: Bright Side of the Moon, and things are about to get intense.]

Walter White: (leaning in with a steely focus, fingers poised over the controller) "Alright, Jesse. This isn’t just some game. This is calculation, precision. Sam and Max? They're the perfect example of how chaos and order can coexist. I’m Sam—orderly, strategic, the one who calls the shots. You’re Max, pure unpredictability. It's how we make it work, Jesse."

Jesse Pinkman: (snickers) "Yo, I’m Max? Hell yeah! You’re right, man—I’m the freakin’ chaos in this world. Max is like me: all about blowin' up the system. This is like some Pink Floyd kind of trip, right? Man, I’m ready to kick some ass, just like I’m breaking bad on these fools!"

Walter White: (gritting his teeth, half-smiling) "You know, Jesse, I don’t think you quite get it. Sam doesn’t go off the rails like you do. He’s in control. He keeps the system in check, unlike... some people." (glances at Jesse)

Jesse Pinkman: (flopping onto the couch) "Yeah, well, I don’t need no rules, yo. That’s what makes Max awesome. He’s the one who’s, like, breaking everything down! You feel me? Like—BOOM! Max is breaking bad on the moon right now!"

Walter White: (nodding in approval) "Alright, Jesse. Let’s see if your version of chaos holds up. I’ll take Sam. I am the danger here, Jesse. While you’re busy causing a scene as Max, I’ll be making the real moves."

[The game begins. The opening cutscene shows Sam and Max driving the DeSoto to the moon. Walter controls Sam, walking with calculated movements, while Jesse’s Max is bouncing around, causing chaos.]

Jesse Pinkman: (laughing) "Yo, look at Max go! He’s like a damn wrecking ball, smashing everything in his path! This is what it’s like when you don’t give a damn about rules! I'm like Max, dude—I’m not here to make friends, I’m here to make an impact!"

Walter White: (staring intently at the screen) "Jesse, you’re a mess. Sam is the one who doesn’t need to rely on impulses. He has a plan—just like me. There’s no alchemy in chaos, Jesse. We work with what we have and make it work. Remember when I told you, 'Say my name'? It’s all about making people respect your power." (Sam gives a sharp, authoritative look.)

Jesse Pinkman: (grinning) "Yeah, yeah—I am the one who knocks, Mr. White. Max is the one who knocks out everyone in this game. Who needs a plan when you’ve got punches like this?" (Max starts throwing wild punches in the game.)

[They reach the part where they must deal with Max’s personified vices: gluttony, sloth, and violence. Jesse, thoroughly entertained, is already ramped up.]

Jesse Pinkman: "Yo, dude—look at this! Max’s vices, right? Gluttony, sloth, violence. Man, I’m like—ALL OF THEM! Ha! I’m a glutton for chaos! This is my world! Just like when I said, ‘Yeah, science!’ It’s my version of science, man!"

Walter White: (serious tone) "You know, Jesse, sometimes—just sometimes—you gotta know when to embrace the chaos. But don’t mistake chaos for a lack of control. Control is everything. And when I say 'I am the one who knocks,' I’m talking about controlling everything in my sight. You’re just... swinging blindly. Sam knows where he’s going, Jesse."

Jesse Pinkman: "Yo, Sam’s cool, I get it. But Max is the one who’s making moves and not worrying about the fallout. It’s like when I told you: I don’t have to listen to your crap anymore. I'm about action—Max style!"

[The game continues, with Jesse's Max causing mayhem and Walter’s Sam working through puzzles methodically. Finally, they reach the epic confrontation with Hugh Bliss, the villain who has hypnotized everyone into seeing the world through his trippy prism.]

Walter White: (gripping the controller tightly) "Jesse, this is it. We’re facing the mastermind, Hugh Bliss. A man who’s trying to control reality itself. Do you understand, Jesse? He’s just like... like every competitor I’ve had in the meth business. He wants to manipulate the world into seeing things his way. But not on my watch. We don’t let chaos win. We control it."

Jesse Pinkman: (snickers) "Control? Nah, man, Hugh Bliss is like that whacko weasel trying to mess with the system. But Max? Max is about blowing it all up. You can’t control everything, man, and that’s the lesson you gotta learn! Sometimes you gotta just let it burn! Like I told you, 'Yeah, Mr. White, I get it.' I’m ready to take this dude down like a meth lab explosion, yo!"

Walter White: (gritting his teeth, voice low) "There’s no breaking bad here, Jesse. I’m not just making moves, I’m making decisions. You want to destroy everything? I’m going to solve this with precision." (Sam shoots the final shot.)

[The moment comes. The final battle ensues. Max is throwing punches left and right, while Sam is calculating his next move to stop Hugh Bliss once and for all.]

Jesse Pinkman: "Ha! Max just kicked some serious butt! Just like when I said, ‘Say my name—Max, the king of chaos!’ I’m the one who knocks, and that’s how it’s done! Hell yeah, man!"

Walter White: (smiling slightly) "I have to admit, Jesse. You were right about one thing. Maybe chaos can win. But, let me be clear, Jesse—I control the chaos. I make it work for me."

Jesse Pinkman: "Yeah, yeah—whatever, Mr. White. But I’m still the one who makes the crazy moves. I break bad, you just break even."

Walter White: (with a small chuckle) "You know, Jesse, maybe the world is a little darker than we thought. But sometimes, you have to let the chaos unfold, just like Pink Floyd said: ‘We’re just two lost souls swimming in a fishbowl’—but we still make it out alive."

Jesse Pinkman: (raising his arms triumphantly) "Yo, you just got all philosophical on me, Mr. White! Hell yeah! I’m gonna go break more stuff, Max-style!"

Walter White: (with a rare grin) "Let’s just hope you don’t break anything else, Jesse. The last time we did that... well, we all remember how that turned out."

[The game credits roll, and the two sit back. The RV is quiet, but for the faint hum of the air conditioner. Pink Floyd’s Dark Side of the Moon can be heard playing in the background as Walter and Jesse continue to banter about the game, both clearly enjoying the bizarre adventure they’ve just completed.]

Jesse Pinkman: "Dude, that was a trip. Max is the man. Sam’s cool, but Max is breaking bad all the way. Next time, we’re going harder. You feel me?"

Walter White: (leaning back in his chair) "I’m beginning to think I might just let you handle the chaos for once, Jesse. But don’t get used to it."

Jesse Pinkman: "Yeah, yeah. Whatever, man. You know what they say: ‘I am the danger.’ And Max is the one who’s always causing it."

[Fade to black, with Pink Floyd’s iconic Time playing softly in the background.]

End Scene.
cleaned_review: Sam & Max: Bright Side of the Moon is as good as it gets.

Reviews:
Très bon début de saison avec cet épisode de Noël très amusant. On retrouve des personnages connus, et Stinky fait son arrivée. La durée de vie est un peu augmentée par rapport à la première saison. Un épisode très réussi ! |  [h1]Title: Futurama Cast Plays "Ice Station Santa")[/h1]

Scene: The Planet Express crew—Fry, Leela, Bender, Zoidberg, Amy, Hermes, and Farnsworth—are gathered in the lounge of the Planet Express ship, playing Sam & Max: Beyond Time and Space, Episode 1: Ice Station Santa. The room is filled with snacks, drinks, and a mix of excitement and confusion as they get into the game.

Fry: (Holding the controller, squinting at the screen) Uh, okay, so we’re in the North Pole, and Santa’s shooting at people. Did I miss something? I thought Santa was supposed to, like, give out presents or something.

Leela: (Rolls her eye) That’s what you think. It’s Sam & Max, Fry. Nothing makes sense. Just go with it.

Bender: (Leans back in his chair, sipping a beer) Yeah, Fry, try thinking with your brain for once. It’s just Santa going rogue. He probably saw an Amazon package and lost it.

Amy: (Leaning in, curious) Wait, wait, wait. Santa’s possessed by a demon? And now we need to fix Christmas... with action figures? This is like if Futurama had a crossover with The Twilight Zone.

Fry: I’m just here for the robot explosions. (He eagerly presses a button on the controller)

Bender: (Nods approvingly) Now that’s the spirit, meatbag. Who needs to worry about plot when you’ve got explosions and ridiculousness?

Zoidberg: (Leaping out of his seat, flailing his claws) Aha! So it’s not just about presents, but about saving Christmas? I love Christmas! But I mostly love the presents... and the food. I bet there’s a Christmas feast waiting for us after we vanquish the demon!

Amy: (Skeptical) Zoidberg, don’t get your hopes up. This game doesn’t seem like it’s about food. It’s more about the absurdity. Like, why are the elves hiding from Santa? And why are we solving all of this with action figures?

Leela: (Shrugs) It’s Sam & Max, Amy. That’s just how it works. There’s no rhyme or reason. One minute you’re fighting a giant robot that’s been sent by Santa, the next minute you're talking to spirits and trying to fix Christmas in three different time periods. It’s like someone crammed every bizarre idea into a blender and hit "Puree."

Fry: (Leans forward, clearly invested) Okay, but why are we using The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse action figures to summon a demon? That’s—wait for it—hilarious.

Bender: (Snickers) You know what I think? I think the real Horsemen of the Apocalypse are going to be awesome. Just picture it: one’s got a sickle, another’s got a giant scythe, and the third one probably does taxes or whatever. Maybe I can be one of them!

Zoidberg: (Picks up a snack, tossing it in the air and catching it) Mmmm... I think they’re all based on some obscure ancient ritual that’s very serious, Fry. (Notices everyone staring at him) You’re not buying that, are you? Fine, fine, it’s just ridiculous.

Amy: (Watching intently as Sam and Max perform the ritual) Oh great. Now we’re summoning the Spirits of Christmas. Past, Present, and Future? This is starting to sound like a Christmas Carol... with action figures and a demon. (Laughs) This is awesome.

Fry: (Chuckling) Yeah, so now we need to make Christmas right in the past. Oh, wait—here’s the best part: We’re fixing a Christmas we totally ruined! I can’t wait to mess up some history! I’m basically Captain Time Travel.

Bender: (Laughing) So the holiday’s all about cookies? Wow. Screw that. I’m in it for the candy canes. They’re like candy... but sharper.

Zoidberg: (Suddenly serious) And don’t forget about the demon Jell-o! That’s what’s going to save Christmas. (Pause) But mostly the shrimp.

Amy: (Sighs in disbelief) Okay, okay, I’m in. This is so weird that it’s brilliant.

Leela: (Nods) Exactly. It’s so ridiculous that it works. We’re in a North Pole nightmare, fixing time travel, summoning spirits, and trying to send a possessed Santa back to Satan.

Bender: (Flipping through a magazine) And don’t forget, at the end of the day, Santa’s still an idiot. What a meatbag. But hey, at least he got to eat the demon Jell-o. That’s a win in my book.

Fry: (Pauses dramatically) Wait, so we’re done now? Do we... save Christmas or what?

Leela: (Smiling wryly) No, Fry. You ruined Christmas. Now you’ll just have to... live with it.

Bender: (Picks up a bottle and chugs it) Oh, I’ll live with it. And then I’ll drink to it, because Sam & Max may be the most insane thing I've ever seen. And I’ve seen a lot.

Enter Hermes and Professor Farnsworth.

Hermes: (Folding his arms) I don't know what kind of foolishness you're all involved in, but let me tell you, Sam & Max is about as organized as my tax returns after a five-day vacation in Jamaica! Santa’s possessed, demons are popping up like bad reviews, and you’re using action figures to fix it?! Ridiculous, man! Ridiculous!

Bender: (Throws up his hands dramatically) Ah, come on, Hermes, lighten up! This is fantastic! It’s got everything—chaos, absurdity, a possessed Santa... and demon Jell-o! What's not to love?

Hermes: (Points to the screen, furious) I’ll tell you what’s not to love: this is exactly why we’re all on the express train to messed-up-ville! You’re playing games while your paperwork is backing up, and I got enough work to fill a mountain of forms! Who’s going to file the tax reports for Santa’s demon-summoning shenanigans, huh?

Farnsworth: (Cackling from the corner, adjusting his glasses) Ho ho ho—this is truly magnificent! The spirit of Christmas is dying, and they’re fixing it with action figures! (Leans in, eyes gleaming) I love it!

Hermes: (Groaning) Not you too, Professor! You’re a man of science! You should be analyzing the logical inconsistencies in this... in this... nonsense!

Farnsworth: (Ignoring Hermes) Oh, but you see, Hermes, there’s a beautiful logic to all of it! The only way to fix this fractured holiday is with absurdity and irreverence! If anything, this game is an expression of pure scientific theory—craziness creates balance! If we can’t fix Christmas with spiritual rituals and action figures, what hope does the world have?!

Bender: (Puffs out his chest) See? Even Farnsworth gets it, Hermes! You’re just mad you didn’t think of using action figures to summon demons first. That’s the true spirit of Christmas!

Hermes: (Throws his hands up) You know what? Forget it! I’m filing my taxes, then I’m getting drunk.

Fry: (Pause as he’s focused on the screen) So, uh, now we have to bring out the three Spirits of Christmas, but we have to fix past Christmases where we messed up. I’m excited. This is like time travel... but with less effort!

Bender: (Laughing loudly) Time travel? Bah! Who needs that? It’s just a reason to mess with history! (He smirks) Why not just change the future to get some extra credits? Oh wait, that's right—I already do that.

Zoidberg: (Frantically running in circles) I’m gonna fix Christmas! I’m gonna fix it! I’m going to save everyone from the demon, and then I’ll feast! (Pauses dramatically, looking around for something to eat) And probably I'll get a nice Christmas ham. Or shrimp... lots of shrimp.

Farnsworth: (Excitedly) Oh, dear boy, you don't fix Christmas with shrimp! You do it with chaos and a few demons! More importantly, we’re creating chaos and rituals by the second! I’m going to write a paper on this... a very important paper!

Amy: (Raising an eyebrow) So… are we actually going to finish this game, or just talk about it forever?

Bender: (Looking at the controller, grinning) Oh, we’re going to finish this game. But let’s take a detour and mess with a few more holiday traditions while we’re at it. It’s Christmas, after all!

The screen fades out to the Sam & Max credits as the crew continues to argue, play, and laugh.

THE END. | Great Christmas Game!
cleaned_review: A very good episode of Futurama.

Reviews:
Si j'ai une préférence pour l'épisode précédent, celui-ci reste très bon et assez délirant. Certaines énigmes peuvent donner du fil à retordre, mais Max vous donnera des indices bienvenus si vous tournez en rond trop longtemps. Toujours très plaisant et drôle. | [h1]Honest Game Trailer for Sam & Max: Moai Better Blues — Featuring a Malkavian Vampire[/h1]

(Dramatic music. The camera zooms in on the title card for Sam & Max: Moai Better Blues. The screen flickers, then a sinister voice over takes over.)

Narrator (deep, gravelly voice):
In a world where logic is optional... and basic principles of physics are definitely optional... a new adventure awaits.

(A bright flash of light fills the screen as Sam & Max rush to the Bermuda Triangle portal. Suddenly, a Malkavian vampire from Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines appears, twitching and muttering to himself.)

Malkavian Vampire (wild-eyed, dramatic):
The symbols! They're all connected! The Bermuda Triangle! The Moai heads! The stop sign! It's a conspiracy, you fools! A cosmic prophecy unfolding before our eyes!

(Sam and Max glance at him briefly, completely unfazed. Sam scratches his chin.)

Sam (nonchalantly):
What, another one? Max, I think we’ve got a new friend.

Max (grinning):
He’s cute. I’m starting to think we should have a Malkavian in every adventure. They really liven things up!

(The Malkavian stares at a stop sign, his eyes widening in terror.)

Malkavian Vampire (screaming):
It’s a symbol! A symbol of the END! IT’S COMING FOR US, YOU CAN’T ESCAPE THE SIGN!

Narrator (snarky):
Oh, that’s right. Sam & Max: Moai Better Blues. The second episode of Sam & Max: Beyond Time and Space, where every plot thread is as twisted and nonsensical as a conspiracy theorist’s notebook... except it’s way more fun, and significantly weirder.

(Cut to Sam and Max in front of the triangular portal. Max gleefully grabs a stop sign, while Sam just looks at it with indifference.)

Narrator (mocking):
*In this episode, things start simple enough—until a triangular portal starts chasing your friend Sybil. But don’t worry! A red octagon is the only thing that can stop it! No, I’m not making that up. This game literally asks you to deal with the greatest puzzle of all time: stop signs. Because logic? Nah, we don’t need that here.

(The Malkavian vampire, in full panic mode, points at the stop sign and gasps.)

Malkavian Vampire (yelling wildly):
IT'S THE END OF THE LINE!! THE STOP SIGN IS THE KEY! THE FINAL PIECE!

Sam (shrugs):
Well, guess we’ll just take it down, Max.

Max (gleeful):
Perfect! We’ll show the universe who’s boss!

(Sam nonchalantly destroys the stop sign with a single tap. The Malkavian stares at it in horror, then collapses into a dramatic faint.)

Narrator (dry):
Then, after all that stop sign drama, you’re going to find yourselves hopping through a Bermuda Triangle, onto the mystical island of Easter Island. Home to the Moai heads, an ancient prophecy, and a volcano that’s really angry.

(Cut to the Moai heads dramatically proclaiming the prophecy in a slow, operatic tone.)

Moai Head (deep voice, serious):
The volcano will rise! And the lava will swallow us whole! The prophecy has foretold it!

Max (looking bored):
Sure, sure, we’ve heard it all before. You’re about to be burned alive, blah blah blah. Let’s just skip to the part where we fix everything.

Sam (nodding):
Yeah, I’m more concerned about this Malkavian guy. He’s probably going to turn into a villain now.

Narrator (sarcastic):
But wait—this isn’t just about lava and bad prophecies. You’ve got puzzles to solve! And who doesn’t love a good puzzle in a game where the rules make absolutely no sense? Like getting rid of a baby version of Jimmy Hoffa to enter a cave, or using a sea chimp to overthrow the ancient high priest of a weird cult. It’s ridiculous, it’s zany, and it’s exactly what you’ve come to expect from Sam & Max.

(Cut to the Malkavian ranting while desperately trying to open a locked door using a stop sign.)

Malkavian Vampire (wild-eyed):
This is it! I can feel the cosmic energy! I’ll stop the volcano with this! No one can defeat the stop sign!

(Sam and Max exchange an exasperated glance before Sam moves to solve the puzzle in five seconds. Meanwhile, the Malkavian continues his raving in the background.)

Sam (deadpan):
I think he’s going to be alright, Max.

Max (grinning):
Yeah, if by ‘alright’ you mean ‘completely bonkers.’

Narrator (chuckling):
This is Sam & Max, after all. Nothing makes sense. But that’s the fun of it. You’ll face a volcano that threatens to destroy Easter Island and... you’ll barely be able to stop it. Mostly because, just when you think you’ve got it all figured out, the game throws in another weird twist, like sending the lava somewhere else, with the help of... a Bermuda Triangle.

(Cut to Sam and Max riding on a giant triangle, surfing away from the eruption as the Malkavian shouts from the background, still stuck in his spiral.)

Malkavian Vampire (yelling into the sky):
They’re flying! The Moai heads are being lifted by lights from the heavens! THE FINAL ASCENSION OF THE PROPHECY IS HERE!

Narrator (incredulously):
Oh, and did I mention that the Moai heads get abducted by aliens in the final scene? Of course they do. Why wouldn’t they? Why stop at lava when you can have extraterrestrial abductions?

(Cut to Sam and Max casually returning to their office after the chaotic events.)

Narrator (mock serious):
So, how do you wrap up a game like this? By returning home like it’s no big deal, of course! You just saved Easter Island from a volcano, survived an otherworldly Bermuda Triangle adventure, and sent a Malkavian vampire into the void... and you still have time to sit at your desk like nothing happened.

(The Malkavian is shown floating into the air, still screaming about the stop sign, lava, and cosmic prophecy.)

Narrator (exhausted, breaking the fourth wall):
Yeah, Sam & Max: Moai Better Blues is a game that makes no sense, yet somehow makes total sense if you let go of any expectations and just roll with the madness.

Text on screen:
"Available now... if you’re ready for the stop signs. Or not."

(The screen fades to black as the Malkavian’s voice echoes off-screen, babbling about the stop sign conspiracy and the ultimate cosmic reckoning.)

THE END.
cleaned_review: Sam & Max: Moai Better Blues — Featuring a Malkavian Vampire[/h1] (Dramatic music. The camera zooms in on the title card for Sam & Max: Moai Better Blues. The screen flickers, then a sinister voice over takes over. Sam and Max rush to the Bermuda Triangle portal. Suddenly, a Malkavian vampire from Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines appears, twitching and muttering to himself. Sam scratches his chin. Sam (wild-eyed, dramatic): What, another one? Max, I think we’ve got a new friend. Max (grinning): He’s cute. I’m starting to think we should have a Malkavian in every adventure. They really liven things up! (The Malkavian stares at a stop sign, his eyes widening in terror.) Malkavian Vampire (screaming): It’s a symbol! A symbol of the END! It’s coming for us, YOU CAN’T ESCAPE

Reviews:
Un 3ᵉ épisode excellent pour cette seconde saison.
La série se renouvelle encore une fois avec le thème de l'horreur, que l'on n'avait pas encore vu. C'est très réussi et toujours aussi drôle. La durée de vie s'allonge encore un peu par rapport aux épisodes précédents. | [H1]Honest Game Trailer for Sam & Max: Night of the Raving Dead — Featuring the Full Cast of Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines[/h1]

(Opening shot: Sam and Max, fully suited in their usual absurd getups, standing in the middle of a gothic, fog-covered graveyard. The moon is high, and a zombie shambles in the background. A funky bass line begins to play.)

Narrator (smooth, funky voice):
Get ready to BOOGIE like it’s the end of the world. Welcome to Night of the Raving Dead, where the undead are dancing, the vampires are grumbling, and Sam & Max… are still somehow the most sensible beings in the room.

(Cut to Sam, looking confused, holding a disco ball.)

Sam (deadpan):
Well, this is new. A zombie rave? Did we miss the memo, Max?

(Max suddenly pops up from behind Sam, spinning a glowstick in his hand like he's at a rave.)

Max (excitedly):
Who cares about memos, Sam?! This is the kind of party I live for! It’s like a rave, but with more death!

(Cut to a shot of a vampire DJ named Jurgen, glowing with over-the-top coolness, cranking up the music in a castle nightclub full of zombies.)

Narrator (excitedly):
*It’s time to boogie down with Jurgen, the vampire DJ who’s here to bring the undead to life… literally. Forget about the old vampire classics, he’s spinning the hottest tracks from beyond the grave—but be careful, because this party gets way out of hand.

(Cut to the Malkavian from Vampire: The Masquerade, suddenly appearing with his arms wide as he starts breakdancing, shouting nonsensical phrases while stumbling through the rave.)

Malkavian Vampire (shouting deliriously):
I hear the rhythm of the dead! The beat controls us all! You can’t escape the groove! BOOGIE or DIE!!

(Sam and Max exchange a look.)

Sam (confused):
Well, that’s one way to enter a party...

Max (grinning wildly):
He gets it! BOOGIE!

(Cut to a bunch of vampire and zombie guests at the rave, all dancing in bizarre, stiff movements as though they’re programmed by some dark force of party chaos.)

Narrator (laughing):
In this hilarious, undead-driven adventure, Sam and Max get dragged into a rave from hell, where the dance moves are as twisted as the mysteries they’ll solve. It’s a tale of soul-snatching, zombie-fighting, and getting down with the most bizarre cast of characters you’ve ever seen.

(Cut to LaCroix, who looks mortified at the chaos of the rave, awkwardly trying to hold a glass of blood punch while standing near a DJ booth. He’s surrounded by glowing zombies doing the Macarena.)

LaCroix (grimacing, quietly):
This… this is beneath me. Vampires aren’t supposed to be this… groovy. What happened to subtlety?

(Suddenly, Jeanette, Damsel, and Velvet Velour arrive, decked out in neon outfits, dancing in circles around LaCroix.)

Jeanette (flipping her hair, teasing):
Oh, darling, you’re doing it all wrong! You’ve got to feel the music. Watch and learn, baby!

Damsel (sassy):
Yeah, Lacroix. Stop being such a stiff! Embrace the BOOGIE!

(Cut to Beckett, who’s in the middle of the floor, casually sipping a drink and nodding to the beat like he's seen it all.)

Beckett (nodding):
Zombies, vampires, glowsticks... At least it’s not another pointless war for dominance. This? This is what life’s about.

(Cut to Gary Golden, casually leaning against a wall with his signature fedora, taking in the chaos.)

Gary Golden (smiling):
Now this is what I call undead culture. I might just stay for the entire rave. These zombies have better moves than half the people I know.

(Cut to Mercurio, who is crouched by the DJ booth, trying to hack into the rave’s speakers while looking totally out of place.)

Mercurio (frustrated):
Great, a rave full of zombies. Just what I needed in my life. I came here for business, not this… music mess!

(Cut to Nines, the gang leader, who’s standing outside of the rave looking entirely unimpressed. He shakes his head as a zombie near him does the worm.)

Nines (grumbling):
This whole thing is just... I dunno, man. Something’s off. But what do you expect from a night like this? These are the kind of raves that drag you into hell.

(Suddenly, Heather shows up, dancing wildly with a plush Max doll, looking completely delighted.)

Heather (giggling):
This is so much fun! I’ve never seen Max so alive—or undead—before!

(Max suddenly swings by in the background, pulling off a ridiculous spin with his undead body, grinning ear-to-ear.)

Max (shouting):
Come on, everyone! Let’s go boogie the night away!

Narrator (mockingly):
In a game where soul-snatching and undead dance-offs collide, Sam & Max: Night of the Raving Dead throws all logic out the window and dares to ask—what happens when you take an epic rave, add in some undead creatures, and let the madness loose?

(Cut to Strauss, who appears slightly disheveled after trying to blend into the dance floor.)

Strauss (tiredly):
Well, I’ll say this... It's not quite the classical experience I had in mind.

(Cut to Jack, who’s in the back of the rave, nodding to the beat with a deadpan expression.)

Jack (laughing to himself):
They said it was the end. What a joke. I thought I'd seen the real end of the world, but this? This is a good time.

(Cut to Skelter, who’s lost in the back of the rave, laughing maniacally to himself while watching all the chaos.)

Skelter (with an insane grin):
The dead are dancing! The living are dancing! Can’t tell who’s who! The whole world’s a disco inferno! HAHA!

(Suddenly, Imalia bursts through the crowd with a fiery, vengeful look on her face, charging the DJ booth to confront Jurgen.)

Imalia (furious):
Enough of this nonsense, Jurgen! I didn’t sign up for this kitsch! If I wanted a rave, I’d have gone to a fashion show!

(Cut to Jeanette, suddenly pulling out a whip and “accidentally” hitting LaCroix in the face, her voice dripping with mock sweetness.)

Jeanette (teasing):
Oops, did I hit you there, darling? Looks like your pride got in the way of the beat. Maybe a little tango would help you loosen up!

LaCroix (groaning, trying to hide his embarrassment):
I am a prince… I don’t need to be dancing to prove anything…

(Cut to Bertram Tung, who’s in the corner trying to teach zombies how to play chess in the middle of the rave.)

Bertram Tung (grumbling):
You all have no strategy! How am I supposed to outsmart a bunch of brainless zombies? Where's the intellectual stimulation in this?

(Finally, cut to Sam & Max, leading the charge in the rave as zombies, vampires, and various Bloodlines characters follow them into the madness.)

Sam (cheerfully):
Who needs saving the world when you can save the night… with BOOGIE?

Max (shouting with joy):
Let’s get this party started, undead style!

Narrator (laughing):
So, if you’re ready for a wild, unpredictable, and thoroughly boogie-tastic adventure, then grab your glowsticks, your best zombie impression, and dive into the dancefloor of Sam & Max: Night of the Raving Dead. Who knew the apocalypse could be this... funky?

(Cut to Sam and Max leading the undead dance circle, as zombies and vampires continue their rave around them.)

Text on screen:
Sam & Max: Night of the Raving Dead. Available now. Come for the boogie, stay for the undead mayhem.

(The camera zooms out dramatically, revealing a zombie DJ spinning vinyl records in a neon-lit castle, with the whole undead crowd getting down.)

THE END.
cleaned_review: A surprisingly good third episode, this is a surprisingly good third.

Game Name: Sam & Max 204: Chariots of the Dogs
Reviews:
[h1]"Chariots of the Dogs: Patrick Bateman's Guide to Absurdity, Existential Crisis, and Mariachi UFOs"s[/h1]

Scene: A pristine, ultra-modern apartment. Sleek chrome furniture. A wall of immaculate CDs arranged by genre and color. A plasma screen television plays a muted version of the Sam & Max intro sequence. The camera pans to reveal PATRICK BATEMAN, dressed in a sharp suit, meticulously polishing a controller. He places it down, adjusts his tie, and addresses the camera with chilling calmness.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
You like Sam & Max?

He pauses, giving the question a rhetorical weight, his expression unreadable.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
Telltale Games released Sam & Max: Beyond Time and Space in 2007, but it wasn’t until the fourth episode—Chariots of the Dogs—that the series truly transcended the bounds of what point-and-click adventures could achieve.

Bateman stands, walking to the CD wall. He selects an album: jazz. Smooth, intricate, complex. The perfect soundtrack to his monologue.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
What’s fascinating about Chariots of the Dogs isn’t just the razor-sharp humor or the immaculate design—although they’re both flawless, I assure you. No, what sets this episode apart is its ability to weave a narrative that is both utterly absurd and profoundly meaningful. It’s like staring into the void and finding it laughing back at you.

He returns to the desk, sits, and gestures to the screen. Sam and Max are frozen mid-dialogue, a UFO looming ominously in the background.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
The story? Genius. Bosco—yes, Bosco, the paranoid convenience store owner—disappears, leaving Sam and Max to unravel a mystery that spans time, space, and dimensions. The humor is biting, like a perfectly executed pun in the middle of a Nietzschean existential crisis.

He smirks, as if the thought amuses him more than it should.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
And the gameplay. Oh, the gameplay. Telltale delivers a streamlined experience, eliminating the clunky mechanics that plagued earlier adventure games. Every click feels intentional, every puzzle a masterstroke of design. It’s like an abstract painting: chaotic on the surface, but with a rhythm that pulls you in.

Bateman’s tone grows more animated as he continues, his hands gesturing to emphasize the points.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
The humor is surreal, sharp. A mariachi band in a UFO? It shouldn’t work, but it does. It’s subversive. It’s daring. It’s... exquisite. The voice acting? Perfectly executed. Every line delivered with precision, every joke landing like a punchline in a room full of philosophers and fools.

He stands abruptly, adjusting his suit in the mirror. His reflection speaks now, cold and detached.

PATRICK BATEMAN (in mirror):
But what really stands out is the ending. Without spoiling it, let’s just say it’s... transformative. A sombrero-shaped UFO and a revelation that changes the very fabric of reality. It makes you question your place in the cosmos, while also making you laugh at the absurdity of it all.

He turns back to the camera, his face suddenly intense, his voice lower.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
You think you’re playing a game. You think it’s just entertainment. But then it hits you—this isn’t just a game. It’s a commentary on existence, a parody of the human condition, wrapped in layers of wit and chaos.

He picks up the controller, holding it delicately, like a rare artifact.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
In many ways, Chariots of the Dogs reminds me of Whitney Houston’s later work—misunderstood by some, but when viewed through the right lens, it’s a masterpiece. It’s sharp, it’s confident, it knows exactly what it wants to be.

He smiles, cold and predatory, then sits again, crossing one leg over the other.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
So, do I recommend it? Let’s just say, if you don’t play Chariots of the Dogs, I pity you. You’ll never understand what it means to truly live. And if you think otherwise, well...

He picks up a silver letter opener, twirls it casually, then places it down with unsettling precision.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
Let’s just say I wouldn’t want to be you.

He leans back, smiles thinly at the camera, and presses “resume” on the game. The screen flickers back to life. The sound of laughter—both Sam’s and his own—echoes in the otherwise silent room.

FADE OUT.
cleaned_review: The slick, sly humor is a tad slack, but the sly, sly humor is a tad sloppy.

Reviews:
[h1]"The Dark Knight and the Clown Prince of Absurdity: A Sam & Max Hellscape Review"[/h1]

Scene: A dark, moody Gotham-esque apartment. Shadows stretch across the walls, a single neon sign outside casting flickering light into the room. The Joker sits on an overstuffed couch, wearing a purple robe and fuzzy bat-themed slippers. BATMAN, brooding and silent, looms in the corner, seated in an ergonomic chair that screams “I’m a tortured billionaire.” A controller sits in Joker’s gloved hands as the game’s opening credits roll. Batman crosses his arms, watching intently.

JOKER:
Maniacal laughter erupts as he wiggles the joystick.
Batsy! Batsy, come here! You’ve got to see this. The dog talks. The rabbit’s probably legally insane. And get this—WE’RE IN HELL! Another laugh, loud and unsettling.

BATMAN:
Gravely.
Focus, Joker. The narrative. What’s the setup?

JOKER:
Spinning in place, then sprawling dramatically across the couch.
Oh, the narrative! You mean the bit where our intrepid heroes, Sam the dog and Max the psychotic lagomorph, stroll into a subway to Hell? Turns out it’s just a few stops below their street! Isn't that just... deliciously absurd? I mean, who designs a transit system like that? Gotham would crumble under that kind of city planning.

BATMAN:
Leaning forward, his face obscured by shadow.
Hell. Satan. It’s symbolic. Tell me—what are the stakes?

JOKER:
Mocking gravitas.
Why, it’s only everything, my dreary detective! Bosco’s soul—yes, our dear paranoid convenience store clerk—is stuck in eternal torment, and Sam and Max have to navigate Hell to free him. Oh, and everyone else’s souls, too. Santa Claus? Check. A sentient car? Check. A Shambling Corporate Presence?! The stakes couldn’t be higher!

BATMAN:
Whispering, barely audible.
Corporate greed. A fitting adversary.

JOKER:
Oh, but wait, it gets better! Satan’s not even the real villain here. Guess who’s running Hell these days? Go on, guess!

BATMAN:
Flatly.
The Joker.

JOKER:
HA! Close! It’s the Soda Poppers. He cackles so hard he nearly falls off the couch. Those pint-sized, washed-up kid actors from earlier in the series? They’ve taken over Hell and turned it into a bureaucratic nightmare.

BATMAN:
Growling, gripping the arms of his chair.
I hate bureaucracy.

JOKER:
Wiping a tear from his eye.
Don’t we all, darling. And the puzzles! Oh, the puzzles! So delightfully twisted! One minute you’re sabotaging Hell’s personal punishment chambers—turning Santa’s toy factory into a sweatshop of cheer gone wrong—and the next, you’re tricking Satan into joining forces with you. Satan, Batsy! It’s a buddy comedy starring Sam, Max, and the Lord of Darkness!

BATMAN:
Standing suddenly, pacing the room.
Satan teams up with... a rabbit? Ridiculous. Implausible. Genius.

JOKER:
Giddy, spinning the controller.
And the dialogue! The dialogue! It’s sharper than a Batarang to the jugular. Every line’s a zinger, every pun a masterpiece of comedic timing. It’s like they wrote this game just for me!

BATMAN:
Pausing mid-pace.
The gameplay. The mechanics. Tell me.

JOKER:
Oh, it’s as smooth as your brooding, Bats. Classic point-and-click, but streamlined. Every puzzle feels like a riddle—one even you couldn’t solve. Except maybe for the one about summoning a demon with a rubber chicken. That one’s obvious.

BATMAN:
Stoic.
Chickens are versatile.

JOKER:
Ignoring him.
And the finale! Oh, the finale! You’d think the Soda Poppers—those annoying little scamps—would win, right? WRONG. Sam and Max trick them into banishing themselves to the fiery depths of a lava pit. It’s poetic justice! The way they scream... chef’s kiss.

BATMAN:
Frowning, deep in thought.
Justice... poetic...

JOKER:
Oh, don’t pretend you’re not impressed, Bats. This game has everything: existential dread, laugh-out-loud comedy, and a wedding in Hell officiated by none other than Max himself!

BATMAN:
Eyes narrowing.
A wedding? Who gets married?

JOKER:
Sybil and Abe Lincoln’s head, of course. What, you didn’t think Hell would freeze over for anything less, did you?

BATMAN:
Mutters, almost imperceptibly.
Makes sense.

JOKER:
Leaping onto the couch, arms spread wide.
So what do you think, Batsy? Shall we make a pact right here and now to call this the greatest game ever made?

BATMAN:
Standing in the corner, shrouded in shadow. After a long pause, he speaks, his voice low and deliberate.
It’s... acceptable.

JOKER:
Mock shock.
“Acceptable”?! You dark, brooding buzzkill! This isn’t just acceptable, it’s a triumph! It’s a carnival of chaos! A celebration of absurdity! It’s...

BATMAN:
Interrupting.
Fine. It’s... a masterpiece.

JOKER:
Grinning wildly.
There we go! Was that so hard? Now come, let’s replay the whole thing together. Maybe this time you can be the one who sabotages Hell’s HR department. He giggles, winking at Batman.

BATMAN:
Walking toward the couch, sitting stiffly next to Joker.
Fine. But if the puzzles are as absurd as you say, I’ll...

JOKER:
Interrupting, holding up a finger.
Ah-ah-ah! You’ll laugh, Batsy. And that’s the best victory of all.

The two sit side by side, controllers in hand. The screen flashes back to life as the theme song plays. The sounds of Sam and Max’s banter blend with Joker’s maniacal laughter and Batman’s grim silence. The camera pans out, leaving the duo in their bizarre truce, united by chaos and the joy of gaming.

FADE OUT.
cleaned_review: The Dark Knight and the Clown Prince of Absurdity: A Sam & Max Hellscape Review

Reviews: A short but fun adventure game.
cleaned_review: A fun adventure game.

Reviews: fun
cleaned_review: The best British comedy of the year.

Game Name: Dangerous High School Girls in Trouble!™
Reviews:
Rarely have I felt as compelled to write a review for a game as I have for this one. Dangerous High School Girls in Trouble (DHSGiT) offers a peculiar type of challenge. It's a game of highs and lows. Whether or not you'll find it fullfilling seems deeply personal in a way I've rarely encountered.

At first glance, DHSGiT appears quirky and charming - undeniably unique. A quick look at promotional material suggests 1920's teenage rebels taking on their school and town with wit and verve. I was excited to install the game. Who wouldn't love mouthing off to authority figures and getting into all kinds of period-appropriate debacles?

Unfortunately, I was met with an immediate wall to my enjoyment. Most encounters in DHSGiT are gated with one of four minigames. This has been exhaustively covered in other negative reviews. The four minigames in question are remarkably dull. If you don't enjoy them the first time, I assure you, you'll hate them by the 100th time. They never give way to something more nuanced. No matter what the circumstance, you'll have to taunt, bluff, hangman, or rock-paper-scissors your way to victory. It's disheartening, I must admit. When I realized that they made up the backbone of the game, I almost quit right out of the gate. I was looking for story, not tedious grinding.

Well, as it turns out, my ex adventure gamer instincts eventually took over. I have (if I do say so myself) a rather high level of tolerance for painstakingly hunting down a narrative.  When I became comfortable with the minigame repetition, I started to enjoy myself. The characters are honestly endearing. Over time, I grew to care about my little girl gang. Every hour I spent with them added more affection. I saw my queen Charlotte as dangerously glamorous. Her second-in-command Jean was everything 1920's society found unfeminine, and I loved it. I was hooked.

Unfortunately, my love was not to last. I'm confused by the last acts of DHSGiT, to say the least. The spoiler-free version of this review is that if you care about these characters, prepare to be heartbroken. The story takes an unexpected and extremely dark turn. I'm all for complex narratives, but this felt rushed and disrespectful to what had come before. I've seen many reviews reference "girl power" as a primary theme of DHSGiT. I think the ending puts the lie to that theory rather thouroughly. I've also seen people recommend this game as "family friendly" or an option for children, which I feel could not be further from the truth. At the very least, make sure to play it through first, to understand the conversations you might want to initiate afterwards.

For anyone that wishes to explore the spoilerific:

[spoiler]For some reason, that I cannot fathom, DHSGiT decides to introduce the theme of sexual assault as a major plot point. Not only is a random member of your gang a near victim (incapacitating her for the rest of the game), but the entire town of Brigiton is complicit in said systemized assault. Very late in the game, the mayor is exposed as a beneficiary of Prima Nocta or Droit du Seigneur. Which is, to say, he is allowed to have sex with any woman in town on the night before her marriage.This is made even more repellent by a subplot in which you arrange the marriage of two of your classmates.  You have, in essence, arranged both their marriages *and* their assaults. I'm not ashamed to say that I felt a bit betrayed. The story doesn't feel so empowering as it does exploitative.  To make matters worse, a noted suffragette has traded the right for women to vote for this violation. It's off-putting and unnecessary. I can't imagine making that trade in good faith. No matter how well meaning, it is beyond fathoming. As a woman, more than anything, I feel like throwing my mouse through my screen. This game touched something unpleasant in a way I never could have expected. I'm willing to acknowledge the parts of DHSGiT that I enjoyed, but it's impossible to forget the parts I didn't.[/spoiler] | Probably the quirkiest offering in recent years, a girl detectives mystery story set in the 1920s, presented as a board game with challenges in the form of card-based minigames. Utterly charming! | When you play this game, all your Call of Dudebro friends will ask you why you're playing a game about high school girls. They might even make some sort of lolicon joke. This is because they are boys and you are a man. A man can play a game about high school girls without feeling his masculinity is threatened. | It's really cool and interesting talking with people like in the 1920's. I don't know how accurate it is -but it's fun.
The game has charm but overall I can't really recommend it unless it's on a really good sale and you don't care about the following cons:

First off to navigate the map you need to put your mouse to the edge of it and wait while it scrolls to the appropriate area.
This quickly gets tedious since it would be very easy to make the arrow keys or something scroll the map without you having to mouse over everytime. It's a needlessly slow process.

The second con and the biggest is that the game is mostly luck based. You have stats you can increase but you will soon realize that sometimes the only reason you lost - was because of luck. You can win with the worst stats and you can lose with the best.
The minigames themselves are a bit fun though. | Cute and unique design, but under that it's four minigames over and over and they're grueling.

Then I read the top review (with the plot spoilers) and I'm glad I didn't force myself through hours of plodding, repetitive minigames just for that.
cleaned_review: I'm not sure what the hype is about, but I'm not sure what the game is about.

Reviews: Best indie game
cleaned_review: The game is a surprisingly good one, and the story is a bit choppy at times, but it's still a good game.

Game Name: STAR WARS™ Knights of the Old Republic™ II - The Sith Lords™
Reviews:
Stuck after combat have legit tried every single possible fix for 3 hours only F4 F5 works but that is so terrible and annoying i'm hoping they fix it such a shame so many people cant play this amazing game. | I enjoy the story but my god is the game stability and saves abysmal. So yes I recommend it but be very careful I had to restart a further back save because there was a setting missing from a .ini file. | Probably the best single player Star Wars RPG out there in my opinion. Mandatory game for any lover of Star Wars or RPG's in general. There are few games that do player-character interaction as well as KOTOR, making the characters on your team memorable even years later. Iconic. 
Make sure you also pick up the "Sith Lords Restored Content Mod", which really improves the game further by re-adding previously cut content due to time limitations in development. | I have mixed feelings about this game it truly is a great game BUT besides the writing being spotty at times and even with all the patches\mods it will always have a chance to bug out on you. The only thing I could say is play at your own risk and keep a lot of saves, throw in some bug fix mods before you play. It's a darker game than the first game but all the Star Wars goodness is here, absolutely recommend it... with a warning tag. | i am such a HUGE fan of the first KOTOR and have played through it a million times. it is the single most impactful gaming experience of my life. BUT, this sequel unfortunately does not live up to the legacy of the first, missing out on the beautiful story, character building, and progression the first game build. i plan on eventually giving this game a full playthrough, but my 70 hours has not led me to believe this game is worth a playthrough.
cleaned_review: KOTOR is a great game, but it's not as good as the first game.

Reviews: This game is really good,not only having tons of lore,but also the hard brain breaking things! This game is absolutely awesome,reccomending it 100% | 2d platform hikayesi güzel ve komik çok beğendim horoz olarak ortalığın içinden geçelm çizimlerde güzel | it is a pog game and a banger sound track | 💋

This game makes me sad. I love it so much but the campaign is impossible to complete. The problem is that the ai can multitask infinately but you are simply a mere human. There's only so many hundreds of tiny ships you can keep track of on screen at the same time. The skirmishes add a lot of replay along with the leveling up but, honestly, if you like this game save your money and get Eufloria instead. It's not as visually pleasing but it's a much better game, hands down. | I purchased this with the express intent of playing co-op, local or otherwise. This game falsely advertises there is co-op when in reality the multiplayer mode is only VS.  There is no way to play with a friend against enemy AI. | I didn't have a lot of hopes and expectations at first out of strategy based space themed game , however, the moment you digest the nuances of game mechanics, it kept on getting bemusingly fun with critter like armies of space orbs and crazy buffooned space-destroyer bosses, this game just starts with a straight Zero at first and kept on multiplying 10X with every other  level and planets. I can't even describe this game, its simple to understand yet the idea is so unique that it warrants a patent. The in-game dialogue and story is a bit naysayer but who cares ? I do !!! | Planets Under Attack is a real-time strategy game.

The gameplay mechanic of Planets Under Attack are simple and not very deep, but it's good, not too easy and need some time to master. You start with a planet, build up fleets and then set out to conquer neutral or/and enemy planets. But you have to make the right decision which planet to attack first and use tactics. The first level of the game could be easy, but when you play deeper into the game, there's when the fun begin.

The graphics of Planets Under Attack is cartoon, but that doesn't make the game a children game. The UI is good and well designed.

Planets Under Attack is another good and fun game. I recommend this.

Rating 8/10 | Got this game on an awesome special so I don't have many greviences. It's a fun game when you are winning but fairly frustrating when you aren't, the reason this is, is not because the game is too hard but rather the game doesn't allow for much variety in strategies. You will restart over and over untill you find the one strategy that works. This makes it an unbalanced strategy game because you may as well watch a bot vs bot match on any RTS and pretend you are one of the bots. With that said, when you are winning it's quite enjoyable and would be a VERY decent game if this feeling was well maintained. If you find it on special it is likely worth whatever experience you get but I would not pay full price.

Reviews:
[h2]Невероятный квест, продолжение истории Эдны и Харви.[/h2] 

Офигительный юмор, отличная рисовка. Что еще сказать? Шедевр. Очень печалит отсутствие русской озвучки и местами не очень логичные загадки. 

[b]Но… все равно - огонь 🔥[/b] | This game is kinda funny.
There is strange logic and unknown potatos... but rabbit will help you to be a good girl. | An absolute gem of a game and on sale for only $2 right now. If you love dark humour, witty writing, a whimsical art style and the nostalgia of the point-n-click games we all played as a kid, this is the game for you.

I played this game when it came but forgot most of the story details. AM I GLAD I FORGOT because, my god, this was a delight to experience with new eyes (GEDDIT) for a second time. It touches on a lot of darker subjects like abuse, loneliness, how we as a society treat children, and the trauma that stems from it. It's actually really deep and satirical underneath all the wonky art and jokes. Like the first game, Edna & Harvey both hold a very special place in my heart. | у игры крайне интригующий концепт и интересная история
грустно, что это не совсем продолжение эдны и харви, но действие происходит в той же вселенной и скорее со сдвигом на доктора марселя. интересно было поглядеть как изменилась психушка в 3 главе, но 1 глава, как по мне, потрясающая, и в дальнейшем игра уже не так хороша
управление упростилось, теперь есть всего две кнопки: взаимодействовать и посмотреть. приятно, что появились кнопки, чтобы скипать диалоги и анимации, без них на все достижения было бы совсем тягомотно пройти
достижения в большинстве своём если не сюжетные, то крайне занудные, типа надуй 99 шариков, поговори с персонажем 20 раз, или сделай какую-угодно любую рандомную херню н-ое количество раз, что без esc, крайне утомляет
так еще и игра забагована, что иногда достижения не выдаются, персонажи становятся невидимыми, съезжают слои картинки, так и вообще можно случайно софтлокнуться на вендиго
я взяла за дёшево в бандле, но полную цену за эту игру бы не отдала
вообщем рекомендую с натяжкой, но если вам не понравится первая глава, то дальше играть смысла нет, так как игра лучше не станет, хотя если вам понравилась первая часть эдны и харви, то будет приятное возвращение в психушку в третьей главе. | Had this game for a long time, and can't complain considering I got it I think in a bundle so it wasn't a total waste of money. But just not a fan of the humor, the puzzles did not make sense most of the time-I do like there's a skip button for the minigames because if I ever did decide to play again, I'd skip them, only played them for achievements-and frankly, all the endings weren't that great in my opinion. Some of the humor was funny and I like the art style, but other than that, not the biggest fan. And I was about to pull my hair out over a bug in the chess minigame that is still not fixed.

One of the most criminally underrated masterpieces in video gaming history, and deserves so much more love than it received at launched in 2012. | 12.5 years later and this game is still top notch. Graphics haven't aged too well; but not a bad visual experience either. Gameplay is excellent and story very good. Hard recommend, one of the best games ever made I'd reckon. Also, got to love how well it runs on the deck. | 玩得废寝忘食不亦乐乎，走路上都怕有老鼠啃我，没有官中生词多如怪物，拼劲全力啃完它，很难形容耻辱有多好玩，耻辱的优点需要条条举例，有宿敌帅老头此为一胜，有长裤帅女王老太此为二胜，有灵活道德底线玩法此为三胜，三胜三胜，胜气凌人，帽子戏法，秒不可言，卓尔不群，玩得小女子芜湖呀呼嘻嘻哈哈咿咿呀呀，虽然评论时只玩了40小时，但实际上我也就玩了5天，五说长不长，说短不短，但足以扰乱我所有的神智，让我的身心都被这个游戏捕获，三回三回，为这游戏我五天内三此差点忘做多邻国 | This game is a long time favourite of mine, its great world, art style, special mechanics, movement and combat, plenty of verticality in the level design and creative options for objective solving, I consider it the best stealth action platformer series period and one of my top games ever, Dishonored is legendary. | 12年的神 箱庭很神 剧情任务很神 杀戮很神 
但你瑪的混乱系统和完美通关屎得满脸喷粪
