Reviews:
In short, the game is very black and white - it's either fun and easy, or a boring tedious grind. There's no happy middle ground, which exists in more carefully and comprehensively made strategy games. It's not particularly buggy, and the points at which this game diverges from most other 4x games are done well, fun and engaging, but it doesn't help basic enjoyment for the same reasons most other 4x games fail. Beyond the first few hours (10-16, depending how slow you play) going through major factions in their scenarios, it's just a grind of not a fun variety. I tried and tried to make it fun, but it's not working.

Only major factions of each scenario are not frustrating to play, but if you play them - it's easy to snowball without any checks and then steamroll everyone. It's ridiculous. Minor factions are doomed to die to a big blob formed by major faction and their con/federation, or get slowly torn apart, with no resources to rebuild because most neighbors are at war with them or refusing to trade anyway, and keep stealing trades in either case. Small emergent factions that pop up during the game are even worse than minor factions. No fun.

Interface is clunky, with misclicks being severely punishing for no good reasons and no ability to remap some crucial controls to make it at least a little less clunky.

Resource management sucks. You either have nowhere near enough of anything for everything you need to begin having fun, or within 10 turns after you solve that shortage - you have so much, that you'll just click on everything you can spend your resources and snowball. Trade is only worth anything if you're short on something in the first 5-10 turns, or try to appease AI faction with gifts (which will come back to haunt you, with all the units and development they get from it).

Military sucks, as per usual in 4x. Seemingly without any economic consequence, AI will keep sh***ing out units with all the bonuses and wear down whatever few units you manage to raise from the crappy start you were given as any minor faction. Or if your enemy is of slightly easier variety - you'll steamroll them, bump up into a big blob on your borders and then get bent yourself, or get locked into a boring slogfest. No matter how much you stack up your bonuses and morale - you're never on par. You're either completely dominant or destroyed easily, and unlike AI you can't spam units to get by without quality - you won't have trade to support that. You can't besiege cities or try to turn enemy units to your side either - because bigger factions will come after you, as soon as that "dishonest" way of fighting ruins your relations with them.

Diplomacy sucks, par for the course in most 4x games. Pointless cooldowns for diplomatic actions, which exist only to get eaten up by trash offers from AI as soon as the cooldown expires, resetting it, and preventing you from offering anything actually useful. Even then, there's practically no point trying to engage with its mechanisms to play peacefully and develop - which is required if you try to keep up with the blob. Returning back to trade, it's incredibly slow to setup and should go in the same trash bin with cooldowns. Other than military force within your own borders, there's no hard counter to "peaceful" units - generals and emissaries, who will screw your plans over, while heroes and sages are practically useless. And there's nothing you can do about them in foreign courts. Trying to force peace between smaller factions, or getting AI into a war is a worthless endeavor too.

Some common scenarios you'll have to go through: You try to make AI players unite against a big blob that threatens you and everyone else - they'll reveal your emissary efforts instead, ruin your relations with the blob, have it declare war on you and kill you with a 1000 cuts. By some miracle you ally to the blob or otherwise keep them appeased? They either break any alliances and good relations to declare war on you, or drag you into their war with another faction - which will inevitably focus on you instead of your "ally". You try to praise the blob to other factions, to raise relations - peace accepted, another war declared soon after anyway.  You're successful and the blob is beaten back? They won't accept peace, and will come back with more units. You beat them properly by destroying them and taking territory? Fun's over - now you're the blob, and the rest of the game goes on easy mode. Capital city and morale mechanics only makes snowballing worse, while countering negatives to that snowballing is too easy to even consider a speedbump. You're lucky and none of that happens? Blob steals your neighboring territory, forcing you to either declare war and lose, or get stuck in slow and pointless peaceful development, before eating you up anyway.

If it's the only 4x you're going to play - it's decent, nothing special against recommending it, especially since it has a very thorough and useful manual. If it's one of a few (2-3) similar 4x games that you'll have in the library and actually play - it will scratch the itch differently, whenever any other one gets boring. But unfortunately it won't be anything special otherwise. | Great 4X game, though has historical maps too. Seems simple at first but I was pleasantly surprised by the level of depth.

Things I love:
- AI does not cheat, ie doesn't get bonuses unless you specifically choose to give it to them. At start of the scenario you can increase their cunning without giving them extra production.
- Resources matter, so you need to plan ahead and consider what you might be short of in 20 turns say.
- Eg Slaves are a resource. So it you have too few slaves, the productivity of your mines are reduced, so it's very tempting to enslave the population of captured settlements.
- Combat is brutal but often your unit will not be destroyed, so you have to consider whether to send them back to heal, or continue the fight
- AI is brutal, and often takes advantage of poor unit positioning by me to wipe out my units
- Trading with AI is well implemented. They consider how valuable each resource is to them, at that particular time, and will consider your trade proposal accordingly.
- Also, you can initiate a trade conversation with offer/request and ask them to propose what they want/offer. So trade is more viable.
- Trade is subject to losses but you can build roads between you and other party's settlements to reduce loss during transportation.
- Trading with immediate neighbours has lower losses so is more lucrative. So you have an incentive to get on with your neighbours...even though that mine of theirs next to your border would really help with your iron shortfall...
- It's harder to paint the map, ie conquer the world. As you grow you gain more corruption, which reduces your efficiency.
- You can make war plans with the AI! Eg I'll declare war on X and attack settlement A in 5 turns, while you declare war on X too and attack settlement B. So you can coordinate wars against powerful factions...and they can do the same to you.
- You can peacefully annex factions, if you get on really well and help them with trades they need.
- Neutral factions (essentially barbarian settlements), will occasionally form a new faction. So they are another player that you now have diplomatic relations with. Happened twice in my current game. So you have to decide, do you want peace with them so you can direct your forces to other borders, or do you want to crush them quickly before these barbarians start developing their lands and making better units.
- If an enemy settlement is well defended, you can siege it by taking the lands around it so its population starts to starve. However, all other factions see this as a war crime and you will damage your relationship with them.
- So much depth, I could go on...

It's largely a war game. You can't easily sit back and play tall. You need to be expanding and attacking your weaker neighbours, or preparing to do so in future. Your neighbours might betray you if you are much weaker than them. | So, the big selling point of the game is that it is "historical" in its mechanics: training a unit directly drains manpower from your cities, if you train in cities that have low morale/loyalty, the units will have correspondingly low morale/loyalty, there's a supply system, yada yada. 

Once you get through the baffling UI and the hit and miss game manual, the game is quite fun. However, you notice quite quickly some weirdly ahistorical things going on such as Rome or Macedon being squashed by their smaller neighbours in 4 out of 5 games (who knew the Samnites and Epirus were actually antique superpowers?), independent barbarian tribes somehow managing an militaro-industrial complex that produces military units back to back with no consequence for their cities or their economy (considering these units have a bonus fighting in hill and forests well...you get thrashed quite easily. Oh yeah, they also raid your mines and temples and cities lol), Sparta popping out babies in the greek wars scenarios as if their crippling manpower and lack of citizens problems was but a historian's drunk rambling...

But I mean, as I said, the game IS quite fun.

However, you sometimes get absolute game-breaking events that kill your fun on the spot. For example, plagues and other disasters. You can turn those off but in my first game with Athens I thought 'yeah, lets see if Pericles dies for real of the plague!" (difficulty: medium).

Well fuck, did he die. Him and 60% OF THE ATHENIAN AND ATTICA POPULATION. Seems like the ancient world got plagues that were somehow twice as worst as the black plague of the 14th century. And it's not like I did nothing - once Athens got hit, I got the "sanitation" decision. Supposedly, sanitation "prevents the spread of the plague" buy emergy building of sewers that last for 5 turns.... Yeah actually that's not true, the turn right after, all of the cities that had sanitation got the plague. There's also an option of martial law for the plague. Did it make a difference apart from making my global happiness plummet to the level of the Styx? Honestly, not that I can tell.

Athens got the plague FOR 12 TURNS, each turn losing about 10% of the pop, which in turn crashes the economy, making it almost impossible to pay the Hoplites and triremes and peltasts, who eventually get the plague as well, which in turn lowers their manpower, making them sweet sweet pickings for the enemies around. In total, my global pop plummeted from 140 pop to about 45. Meanwhile Sparta got it, had it badly for 8 turns and voila! No more plague! Also, thanks to their super effective baby-Agoge producing facilities, I got steamrolled pretty easily afterwards. 

In the end, the game is still quite fun, like a more complex Civilization game, but be aware that sometimes the fun just goes running out of the window naked because of baffling gameplay choices from the devs (an earthquake followed by a flood of the tiber on turn 15 of my second Rome game? really?? ok I got my lesson, no more "disasters" option). | So far 8/10...Review to be updated... | Really liking this game so far.

Reviews:
I've played this game for years on and off and during that time I've gotten quite good at it - having even risen the ranks to the top 25 on the leader board with my brother in a couple seasons.

With the number of hours I'd played I even spent over 100$ supporting the game by buying skins and what not. I enjoyed the flow, the challenge, and the strategy. I know every card. How they're played. How they're countered. 

So why am I giving it a negative review now?  I recently came back to it to find out the game had completely changed. 

Why oh why have the devs decided to remove wild cards (doubles of the same card in the same deck) and duplicate cards (the same card in your teammates deck) in premade team battles?? Half the fun of this game was being able to strategize with a friend and come up with crazy combos, thematic decks, and sometimes just plain goofy ridiculous decks early in the league. I strongly believe the percent chance of drawing a deck defining card or executing your intended combo is a key element of dueling cards in general. Think Magic or Yu Gi Oh. Now a huge part of that fun and build design is just gone.

Effectively, they've changed the game that I originally fell in love with and after over 800 hours I don't think I want to play anymore. What a shame. | Rating: 7/10

Overview: Minion Masters is a fast-paced, free-to-play strategy game that blends elements of tower defense and collectible card games (CCG). Developed by BetaDwarf, the game pits players in 1v1 or 2v2 battles where they summon and control minions to battle against their opponent’s forces, all while managing a deck of cards. With its unique mix of gameplay styles, Minion Masters offers an accessible but strategic experience for fans of both strategy games and card battling.

Gameplay: In Minion Masters, players build and use decks of cards to summon minions, cast spells, and build structures on the battlefield. Each card corresponds to a different type of unit, spell, or structure that players can deploy in real-time. The key to success is not just about deploying powerful units but also about managing your resources (mana), timing your plays, and reacting to your opponent’s strategy.

The game offers several different modes, including standard 1v1 and 2v2, where players can compete against other players or AI. The matches are quick, lasting around 5-10 minutes, which makes it easy to jump into a game and not get bogged down by long sessions. The action is fast-paced, with constant back-and-forth gameplay, making it exciting for those who enjoy real-time strategy with a bit of card game strategy mixed in.

Deck Building and Strategy: The strategic depth of Minion Masters comes from deck building. Players can collect new cards and customize their deck to suit their playstyle, with different minions, spells, and special abilities available to choose from. The key to winning is finding the right balance between offense and defense, while also considering synergy between the cards in your deck. There are a variety of minion types, each with strengths and weaknesses, which adds an extra layer of tactical decision-making to each match.

Progression and Monetization: As with many free-to-play games, Minion Masters includes a progression system where players can unlock new cards and cosmetics by earning rewards from matches or purchasing card packs. While the game is generally balanced and not pay-to-win, there is an option for players to spend money on card packs and other cosmetic items. This could give some players a slight advantage early on, but most progress can still be made through regular gameplay.

Graphics and Performance: Minion Masters features bright, colorful visuals with a somewhat cartoonish art style that fits the fast-paced, playful nature of the game. The minions and spells are well-designed, with each card having its own unique look and animations that help bring the battlefield to life. The game runs smoothly on most systems, and the controls are intuitive, making it accessible for both new players and strategy veterans alike.

Audio Design: The sound design in Minion Masters is solid, with an upbeat soundtrack and engaging sound effects that add to the excitement of the battles. Each card and minion has its own set of sounds, from the footsteps of marching troops to the explosive effects of spells, helping to immerse players in the game’s action. The voice lines of the minions and the announcer are charming and add some personality to the game.

Challenges: While Minion Masters is accessible, there is a learning curve when it comes to building effective decks and mastering the timing and positioning of your units. As players unlock more cards, they can start building more diverse strategies, but the game’s fast pace means you need to react quickly, which can be challenging for newcomers. The game also features matchmaking, but occasionally, you may find yourself up against opponents who have stronger cards if you're not progressing quickly enough.

Final Thoughts: Minion Masters is a fun and fast-paced strategy game that offers a unique blend of collectible card gameplay with real-time strategy. Its quick matches, deck-building mechanics, and strategic depth make it an enjoyable experience for players who enjoy both card games and strategy games. While there’s a progression system that could feel grindy at times, the game remains accessible, and its focus on skill and strategy makes it rewarding for those who stick with it.

Pros:

Fast-paced and accessible gameplay
Strong strategic depth through deck-building and unit placement
Bright, colorful visuals with appealing animations
Free-to-play with fair monetization options
Multiple game modes including 1v1 and 2v2
Cons:

Progression can feel slow at times
Pay-to-progress elements, though not pay-to-win
Some balancing issues, especially at early levels
Can become repetitive if not switching up strategies
Minion Masters is an enjoyable strategy game for those who like quick battles, tactical decision-making, and card collection. While there are some minor progression hurdles, the game offers a solid and fun experience for fans of competitive, strategic gameplay. | This game was fun for a while. I found it late thinking it was a new game. After several months of loving it and playing it almost daily; the fun is now at its end. Nothing new is coming to it. | "Если бы мне сказали, что я буду проводить ночи напролет, крича на экран из-за толпы миньонов, я бы не поверил. Но вот я здесь, с кругами под глазами и улыбкой до ушей. Minion Masters — это как смесь покера, шахмат и цирка, где все участники слегка не в себе.

Что мне нравится:

Миньоны-психопаты. Серьезно, кто еще будет бросать летающих свиней в драконов? Это гениально!

Стратегия? Шутка? И то, и другое! Ты думаешь, что всё продумал, но тут твой противник выкидывает карту, которая превращает твою армию в лягушек. Лягушек, Карл!

Быстрые матчи. Это как фастфуд, только без угрызений совести. 5 минут — и ты либо герой, либо лузер. Но в любом случае хочется еще.

Что не нравится:

Случайные карты. Иногда тебе выпадает такая рука, что хочется плакать. Но это часть веселья, правда?

Итог: Minion Masters — это идеальная игра для тех, кто хочет немного адреналина, много смеха и возможность почувствовать себя злым гением (или просто неудачником с хорошим чувством юмора). Если вы еще не играли, то что вы вообще делаете со своей жизнью?

P.S. Драконы — это круто. Свиньи — тоже. Но драконы на свиньях? Это просто бомба. 10/10, играю дальше." | great game no complaints. been playing since it released.
cleaned_review: Minion Masters is a strategy game that is a hybrid of strategy games and card battling.

Reviews:
I am deeply and truly shocked by how GOOD this game is.
It looks simple and it is easy to learn but its mechanics are very deep and complex. Take sea battles, for example. For a start, you have a simple ship with simple cannons. They can shoot... and that's about it. But! Even at this early stage you see glimpses of the deep that hides under the surface. Because your ship, simple as it is, has 3 different speeds according to the wind's direction, cargo space, hull strength and crew... which consists of distinct characters, every one of which can be trained in any unlocked class, equipped with your chosen weapons, trinkets and consumables. Why is it so important? Because during sea battles you can board all enemy ships and even many of the sea monsters - and they can board you - initiating a tactical battle using your crew! And this is only the beginning. Your cannons have different firing distances and firing angles, you can find and/or buy beam cannons, lightning cannons, slowing cannons, cannons that freeze enemies and even water on the map, cannons that have 360 degree firing angle, cannons that damage enemy crew... You can add a lot of different ships to your fleet - ironclads, living regenerating ships, even some of the monsters that you fight. 
Simple in concept, very deep and satisfying in further study.
It can be said about land (or boarding) battles also. You are controlling a party of 5 characters each of whom can have a combination of 2 classes chosen freely that give you all told about 12 active abilities to use in battle... for EACH CHARACTER. We are looking at a whopping 60 abilities in total - and it is without taking into account different consumables and weapons that your characters can have. As a bonus - enemies are working under the same rules as you. They can also have these classes and abilities. They can also have these weapons and consumables. And they can use them pretty intelligently. And this is not all! Maps themselves are no less important. They are full of different hazards, height differences and opportunities. Push an enemy off a cliff! Push an enemy into a wall! Push an enemy into another enemy! Rain water onto them! And then electrify or freeze it! You can walk on ice, you can chop down trees, you can cut or burn away grass, you can blow up walls... Battlefield is changeable and destructible - and it is glorious.
I can rant for a long time, but I'll stop here. Horizon's Gate gives players a large and beautiful world to explore and plunder. I've bought this game on sale because it is the first game from this developer for me and I was not sure I'll like it. I've already bought their next game - Kingsvein - at full price without a doubt. Because I am sure now.
And I hope that we will see Horizon's Gate 2 someday. Sea exploration and battles gel very nicely with amazing tactical combat and a vibrant world that this developer created. I want more. | Que jogo sensacional
Exploração bacana com um mundo grande, com várias dungeons (apesar que simples, sendo que a maioria são só duas salas) e muitas cidades, combate tático que não depende tanto da movimentação e ambiente, mas que entretêm, principalmente pelo sistema de classes, que é viciante e a cereja do bolo é a trilha sonora, que é excelente
O foco tá longe de ser a história, mas é legal e tem uma dungeon inteira fora da casinha pra explicar ela
Não instalei muitos mods, mas tem vários que adicionam muito conteúdo, como quests, locais, classes, mudanças no gameplay, etc.
Se esse jogo tivesse um orçamento um pouco maior para aprofundar o lore dos personagens e os gráficos, seria uma obra prima | Great game that punches way above its weight class. The job system, ship combat, general exploration are all great. I would like to see more of this. The tactical elements are way better designed and implemented than 95% of other tactical rpg type games. | This is a really fun and surprisingly addicting game. If you like exploration in games, tactics games, and role-playing games you will love Horizon's Gate. I really like sailing around, trading, and discovering new areas on the map. Building your landing crew for the FF tactics-esque combat is also a lot of fun. I do wish more of the recruit-able party members had a bit of a personality. But, this is a more game-play focused game so I can let it slide. Overall it is a great deal full price and actually a steal when it goes on sale. I'm leaving this review so hopefully this game can get more attention :) | What a hidden gem of a game.  For those familiar with old'school Uncharted Waters, FFT, and Ultima, this game is a perfect fit.  Tons of classes to work for throughout the entire game without ever really feeling overwhelmed with the options.  Highly recommended even at regular price.

Reviews:
Sehr befriedigendes brettspielartiges Strategieerlebnis. Mir gefällt besonders, dass es ein Aufbauspiel ohne militärische Komponente ist. Jede Art Planet hat "Rezepte", wie man ihn nutzen kann, wenn man ihn kolonisiert. Es geht darum, ein florierendes Netzwerk zwischen den Planeten aufzubauen. 

Dabei gibt's eine Vielzahl von Problemen zu managen: Am Anfang fragt man sich, lieber schnell etwas zum Laufen bringen, um frühes Geld zu verdienen oder lieber erst die ganze Umgebung entdecken, um die Konstellationen zu optimieren? Im mittleren Spiel sollte man neben den klassischen Strategie-Dilemmas (zuerst Wirtschaft ausbauen oder Forschung?) immer auch die bestehende Infrastruktur im Blick haben - oft entstehen im Spielverlauf noch Möglichkeiten zur Verbesserung. Und gegen Spielende willst Du immer mehr expandieren, aber ab einer gewissen Anzahl Planeten wird alles exorbitant teuer. 

Hohe Varianz durch die Auswahl der Völker beim Spielstart. Die Völker haben eine klare Identität (auf welche Spielmechaniken und Spielstile sie sich beziehen), aber in jeder Partie bieten sie eine andere Auswahl an Technologien aus ihrem Pool an. Dadurch spielen sich die Partien vom Anfang bis Schluss sehr unterschiedlich.
Im Standardmodus gibt es zusätzlich noch "Modifikatoren", die die Eigenschaften der Karte verändern, auf der man spielt. Die sollte man für die ersten Runden erstmal ausschalten, weil das Grundspiel schon abwechslungsreich genug ist. Wenn man das Spiel besser kennt, sind sie sicher eine willkommene Abwechslung.
Es gibt auch eine Kampagne mit etwas mehr Story, aber ich finde den Standardmodus eigentlich genau richtig! | It's fun. I like it. It's the sort of space-based resource management game that appeals to my brain. Getting things to work is very satisfying! Not having that ONE RESOURCE you need within range is VERY FRUSTRATING! It's a good game to start up when you want to play SOMETHING and aren't sure what. Standard runs are pretty quick. There's still plenty of the game that I haven't interacted with, yet, at 10 hours in. If it looks like the sort of thing you would also like, I highly recommend it. | The game seems simple at first but optimizing for maximum efficiency is very tricky and satisfying to learn. Discovering all the interactions between mechanics has been very addicting and fun. Instantly one of my favorite games of all time. | Un bon jeu d'optimisation en environnement incertain. C'est paradoxalement un bon jeu de détente où le fait de se casser la tête n'a pas d'autre implication que d'avancer plus loin dans le temps et d'avoir un meilleur score. 
But du jeu: coloniser des planètes pour obtenir des ressources, qui elles-même demandent des ressources. Il faudra donc explorer votre espace, coloniser des planètes, puis les relier entre elles (sans croisement, d'où la difficulté). Un fois établie, de nouvelles ressources sont demandées, etc.
Le retour dans le temps permet aussi de faire des tests si on est pas sûr à 100% de notre coup, ou si on fait une erreur (attention cependant, il n'est valable que si les inconnues le reste, donc pas d'exploration). Les parties sont assez courtes (entre 1 et 2 heures selon votre réflexion), et la rejouabilité assez énorme (entre les bonus de races, les technologies, les types de systèmes et les anomalies si on les actives, on a de quoi faire).

En bref, un bon jeu de réflexion (d'optimisation) qui vous fera perdre la notion du temps. | Slipways is refreshingly different by being simple and compact. It's core loop is satisfying and the hard turn cap is very well balanced, keeping the game from dragging on well past your failure or success. It's the little box that makes my colony level 2.
cleaned_review: gotten to play yet.

Reviews:
I would be willing to recommend this game with a couple of caveats. The game is extraordinary detailed. There is a huge potential in the game for replay and replay and replay. My issue with this game is it does tend to be painfully tedious. There is no real guidance as to what a player should be focusing on within a particular journey to the end. If the goal is a Military victory, that's pretty basic stuff. Everybody knows how to accomplish that. But if a player decides not to pound all the others into oblivion, it can become a bit problematic trying to figure out how to "win".
I just finished playing a game to the 500 turn limit, and lost.  I have no idea why. I was first to the moon, I was first to the A-Bomb, out had the most Democracy points. I had no idea what I should have been doing to secure a non-military victory. The game has no graphs, no information about each type of possible outcomes, no information on where you stand relative to the other players. The game just ended with a DEFEAT screen, nothing....
I have no intention of playing this game again until there are appropriate updates to the game. That said, the game has a HUGE amount of potential it's obvious a lot of thought has already gone into the development and I do wish for more from this title | After probably 25 years of gaming on and of steam, this is my very first review. Why? Because I want a roadmap for 2025! In my oppinion this game deserves it!

The game is imo the best competitor to CIV as of now, with fresh ideas, regarding replay (timeline can be changed significantly by choosing), tile system and strategy (focus trees). 
Each of the ideas are great, I love the immersion that they generate, which are not broken by the alternative histories. Damn I even love the graphics; they feel more realistic than Comic CIV 6. 

The game for sure has it's weaknesses, especially in CPU AI (weaker than CIV, but similar problems), balance (the game for sure is not perfect for Min Maxers), and the super prolonged late  game (CIV has a similar problem)

So the game is definitely not for everyone (especially min maxers won't like aspects). But in my oppinion it brings enough fresh air to be exciting for a lot of hours. Hopefully the game gets a roadmap for 2025! | CIV war gestern! 
Ich habe sämtliche Teile CIVILISATION Runde um Runde gesuchtet und deshalb viele Stunden Schlaf verloren. Doch Paradox hat es endlich geschafft den behebigen König vom Thron zu stoßen. Da wo sich CIV immer wieder in überheblicher Selbstherrlichkeit neu erfunden hat und am Ende doch jedes mal wieder nur langweilig an der Oberfläche geblieben ist, weil irgendwelche interessanten Spielmechaniken rausgeflogen sind, legt Millenia erst richtig los. DER KÖNIG IST TOT! LANG LEBE KÖNIGIN MILLENIA! 

Wie so oft bei Paradox dauert es zwar eine Weile bis ihre Spiele die Kurve bekommen, aber mit den beiden DLC´s ist es jetzt mein klarer Favorit in der gesamten X4 Welt! 

Okay an manchen Stellen wirken die ansich interessanten Entscheidungen etwas deplatziert, wenn man z.B. einen Händler mit Diplomatiepunkten erkauft oder Religion mit Kultur, aber die zugrunde liegende Spielmechanik finde ich dennoch sehr viel besser als bei vergleichbaren Titeln. Ich denke hier wird noch ordentlich was kommen und es ist in meinen Augen viel spannender als bloß immer nur alle Punkte (Bau/Forschung/Kultur, etc.) nach oben zu treiben wie bei CIV. Bei Millenia muss man sich viel öfter für einen Weg entscheiden und dafür andere (auch) gute Vorteile erst einmal liegen lassen.

Klare Kaufempfehlung!! Insbesondere wenn Du so wie ich bei den Ankündigungen zu CIV VII die Hände über dem Kopf zusammengeschlagen hast ; / 

Jetzt ist es eine kleine Liebeshymne für Millenia geworden... aber zurecht, danke ins Paradox-Team! 

F*** CIV6,7,8,9,10. I´m out finally! | tl;dr - Not recommended at full price, but a fun diversion at a discount

The game offers some interesting ideas but in the end, if you're looking for a 4X fix, there are better options.

I found the graphics decent, particularly the geography. Unit graphics, especially in the battle viewer, are more lacking, and their animations especially so. Watching a three-deck ship of the line bouncing like a bathtub toy when hit in battle, or a knight charging across the screen while his horse's legs remain still are somewhat immersion breaking.

I like the Ages mechanic. it offers a good way to put together broader changes in society with the advance of time and technology without making everything ever done a separate individual technology. I particularly liked that barbarians go away after reaching a particular age. The variant ages are an interesting idea, allowing small changes to gameplay.  The downside of the ages is that technologies are unlocked by the ages and have no other prerequisite, leading to some definitely ahistorical progressions.

Different unit types are a good idea but they didn't actually have a big impact on my own play style. I mixed my armies and navies up a little and otherwise forgot about it.

Your opponents are pretty interchangeable. The difference between China and Rome and Canada are just the colors of their banners.

I found domestic trade routes very frustrating. A region can only trade with one other region, regardless of how many different trades they can have, which means you can't easily establish a region to, for example, supply oil to the rest of your empire. Or be the equivalent of Pennsylvania and send steel to Detroit and New York for their industry. This is perhaps the biggest failure in my opinion.

I found vassals to be a so-so idea. they provide passive income to you but they also don't defend themselves. All cities do have militia to defend themselves even if there are no units garrisoning them, but vassals can't create additional defensive units. They'll also leave pillaged improvements unrepaired, even when they're able to build new ones. The urge was often strong to take over a vassal, fix their crap, and then release them again just so I didn't have to see burning farms turn after turn.

No aircraft carriers in the game. WTF? The only mobile defense against enemy bombers on land or sea is providing fighter cover. Making outposts is certainly a way to extend the reach of your air force but many times I had to advance without air cover for my armies or navies.

Late game performance is frustratingly slow. I set my regions to work on a colony ship and then spent the last twenty or thirty turns just clicking 'end turn' and waiting 30 seconds so I could click it again. My system is less than recommended, though, being a Ryzen 3600X with 36GB RAM. | Disclaimer: I have not played multiplayer, as it wasn't funcional at game release. 

The graphics primitive, but very functional. UI works. I didn't encounter any major bugs or crashes.

Choosing a civ at the start is entirely cosmetic, but I thigk all things considered that that is a plus. Flavor/Culture is instead derived from national spirits that you pick each age. It solves the feeling of cultural stagnancy that sticking with a static civ throughout the game gives, allowing for a civilizational narrative, but without without breaking immersion (as in humankind and presumably civ 7 when it comes out) due to switching to discontinuous cultures, such as transforming from Sumeria to the Celts, Ethiopia to China, or Inca to France.

Ages are pretty neat. They veer into mythology alternate-history and science-fiction, and make for a lot of replayability, as your options and short term objectives can vary wildly between games. The world itself is reactive to the actions of players. Researchable technology differs based on through which age you progress into. Crisis and Challenge ages are damaging/powerful. Being able to plunge the entire world into chaos with an age of plague, conquest, or the AI uprising, for instance, with your own actions is fun in singleplayer (it might get annoying If you are behind in multiplayer, I wouldn't know.) They also are focal to winning, as different ages offer different win conditions. Being ahead of your opponents at the right time is critical to securing victory.

Internal empire management in this game is really fun and engaging. Setting up supply chains which develop in complexity as technology progresses is very satisfying. It makes natural resources on the map feel much less interchangeable than other games. For example, rice and wheat can both be processed into flour, but rice can also be used to make wine. Best in class in my opinion.

The combat is passable, and not really a focus of strategic gameplay. You build units, move stacks around on the map put in a leader for a % strength bonus, Rock paper scissors, the armies do a little auto-battle thing which shows how the battle went.

Overall, pretty good. Has some unique and good ideas that seperate it from the rest of the genre, definitely not a clone as some have said.

A ton of fun and easy to play and understand for players of all ages. Highly recommended!

Reviews:
This one had a really really rough start on the steam deck, but I am glad I stubbornly returned to it and attempted to make it work. It sucked me in for about three weeks, and now that I am at the end, as much fun as it was, I am glad I'm about to be done.

The gameplay is rather simple: Sidescroller action RPG, you have a shield, a melee weapon, and can unlock a throwing weapon. 3 stats, 6 gear slots, 4 skill trees. You use food to explore the map, discovering new places to travel to, and after clearing them, you can send your workforces to harvest materials: food, wood, stone, etc. which you then use to build your settlement.

While I have a forge, I never actually forged something. Drops were just good enough, and while they aren't overly exciting (mostly just stats go bigger), one or two weapons had nice gimmicks. I never really ran out of materials, though I sometimes had to scout a bit to find more leather or food.

The quest log is more or less useful, leaning towards less. All entries get just listed one after another, and it doesn't mention where something happened. One of my map locations bugged out and had a permanent blinking quest marker on it, while at least one other just kinda. Vanished? I know I had a quest to help some dude across a chasm, but at some point, it was just gone. Was the quest giver killed? Who knows!

Speaking of, there are bounties which spawn once you accept them. I wasn't too amused to realize that those bounties take out friendly NPCs in those locations - especially as one of those locations had wolves I could have taken as followers!! NOT THE PUPPIES!!

Followers. Eh. Without a fully upgraded training ground, they just died on me constantly, and I was playing on easy. You also can't leave them at the camp, so I lost my doggo in a siege event. Sad.

While most areas focus on combat, there are a few containing puzzles. Especially the main quest "light the beacons" maps are heavy on the platforming. As someone who hates platforming, it wasn't super hard, but it also wasn't fun. The achievements were all pretty easy to get, and are not tied to the story in any way, all just numbers, so I was done with them long before the end of the story.

The controls take some getting used to. A and D move sideways, that's normal, but W is used to jump, which is not. S is used to go down platforms, but I was unable to go down ladders with it. Who cares, no fall damage, just jump off. I had to rebind a few keys to make it work without me wanting to rip my hair out.

I know this all sounds negative, but what can I say, I was having fun. This game had the perfect low effort gameplay loop I was craving, slowly making my progress across the map, just one more location, one more, one more. While not really gameplay relevant, the different biomes were nice, the pixel is art pretty, and I just had what felt like a constant sense of progression across the board. I don't see much replay value, but I got almost 24 hours out of a game for less than 5 euro on sale, and I think that's pretty neat.

Steam deck specific reasons I cannot really recommend it there (despite having played it on the deck): 
- The launcher is annoying. All launchers are annoying.
- You have to crank interface size way down, because it does not play well at ALL with low resolutions, which makes navigating the map especially tedious. Everything is so small! At the start, every few minutes, I shrank it down another little bit because there was something cut off. Imagine my surprise when I found buttons to press in the corner of the map.
- I didn't give the actual controller support much of a chance, because nothing was explained, jumping was so weird, and I couldn't even figure out how to talk to a guy, and in the end, I just downloaded a much-used community layout and adjusted it for what I needed. I don't think I would have been able to play with either default controls or any of the existing community layouts. | Muito divertido, formas diferentes de jogar e boas referencias. | ★★★☆☆ | 7/10
cleaned_review: I'm not sure what to say about this game, but I'm glad I'm done with it. It's a simple side-scroller action RPG, and you have a shield, a melee weapon, and can unlock a throwing weapon. The quest log is more or less useful, leaning towards less. All entries get listed one after another, and it doesn't mention where something happened. One of my map locations bugged out and had a permanent blinking quest marker on it, while at least one other just kinda. Vanished? I know I had a quest to help some dude across a chasm, but at some point, it was just gone. Was the quest giver killed? Who knows!

Reviews:
Easily my favourite Total War. In my opinion, the best battle game play by far. It just feels smooth where it needs to be, sharp and responsive and I appreciate the aesthetic design throughout, not just because of the Japanese theme, but the overall tone of the artwork. Also arrows are effective which is nice to see in a TW game. 10/10 and then some with workshop mods. | Total War: Shogun 2 - это суровый мир самураев, династий и стратегических сражений, который сразу же захватил мое внимание. Эта игра не просто стратегия, это целая эпоха, в которой каждый выбор может изменить ход истории. 

Плюсы:
1. Сюжет игры, основанный на исторических событиях, позволяет взять на себя роль одного из кланов и вести его к власти. Это не просто борьба за территорию, но и глубокая стратегическая игра, где нужно учитывать политические интриги, дипломатические отношения и экономическое развитие. Каждый выбор имеет значение, и это придает игре особую глубину.
2. Атмосфера Японии периода Сэнгоку передана с невероятной детализацией для игры 2011 года: от красивых пейзажей до неплохо проработанных юнитов, каждый элемент создает ощущение погружения в игру.
3. Музыкальное оформление заслуживает отдельного лайка! Звуки природы, традиционная японская музыка и эпические мелодии во время сражений создают уникальную атмосферу, которая усиливает погружение в игру.
4. Огромный плюс игры в том, что какую-никакую кампанию можно проходить с другом! Это очень круто, весело и дает больше разнообразия для совместных стратегических действий.

Минусы:
1. Иногда искусственный интеллект может показаться не совсем адекватным, а некоторые элементы управления слишком топорные и требуют времени на привыкание. 
2. В некоторых моментах игра может показаться медленной, особенно в начале, когда нужно развивать экономику и строить армию (на что уходит куча времени).

Total War: Shogun 2 - это великолепное сочетание стратегии и истории, которое оставляет после себя теплые эмоции и желание вернуться в этот удивительный мир. Если вы любите стратегические игры, серию Тотал Вар и просто хотите на чилле/на расслабоне погонять самураев по карте, то, игра вам определенно понравится. | Fuck you corpos for destroying a great game! Can't run mods, and without em still crashes, thx assholes | 全战里最喜欢的一代，即使是十年前的游戏在今天看来依旧雄风犹在，使用reshade后画质甚至已达到了电影级，再者幕府2作为开山之作幕府1的续作，发售之后再次成为全战不得不品的经典之作，全战系列除了几个外传没买都已经有了，战锤3可能对于战锤这个ip来说是史诗级游戏，但作为一款全战来说，我个人而言对此并不满意，单从战斗方面来说，幕府2的精密细节水准无出其右，也是第一部着重于pvp对战平衡来制作的全面战争，在当时具有跨时代的意义，在幕府2之后发售的罗马2则开始沦为血条全战，以及之后的所有作品，全都不再是1对1的战斗，而是血条制度，战斗细节逐渐敷衍，空气刀逐渐盛行，玩起来已然失去了全战该有的精髓，食之无味弃之可惜，这些就像在玩传奇一样无趣，就连战前演讲的设计也被废除了，只有特定的事件战役才有战前演讲，不知是说他越做越大了还是越来越商业了，除了堆量卖dlc就是敷衍中的敷衍，ca的新作法老就是一个最好的例子，也别提因为想要为法老引流宣传对老作品进行强制更新的操作，玩家曾尝试退版本来抗议，但ca一意孤行不为所动，并禁用了退版本的功能，此举导致了幕府2的mod社区遭受重创。地图模组全部失效，武家之殇的mod也出现一些闪退无声音的问题，pvp的聊天功能被删除，除此之外未对游戏推出任何的实质性更新内容，社区管理也只是一味的捂嘴不让说，禁止提出建议，仿佛在ca眼里，他们忠实的老玩家已失去了利用价值，只有迎合战锤的新玩家才是ca目前的摇钱树和救命稻草，三国的停更导致只到汉末，三国也是名存实亡，ca时至今日可惜还是未曾吸取教训，仍然拒绝沟通，一意孤行已成为常态，就看ca他这种态度还能走多远，小心，法老的失败已经使得世嘉逐渐失去耐心，也是不得不重新评估你ca的实际可存价值，下一作如果还是法老这种质量，那离解散重组已不再遥远



最后给大家推荐一下我自制的一个系列，亡灵侵袭，在经历一年的更新后已基本成型，已分成12家族版本，整合了工坊一个我觉得不错的类148城mod，加上目前的一共拥有66个新兵种，可玩性max

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3156978735 | Total War Shogun 2 is a great game. I picked it up for only 7ish bucks, and it was definitely worth it. The actual time period is one of my favorites, and the archer units are EXTREMELY satisfying in my opinion. Only complaint though is the fact that it does sometimes crash and it will just break in the loading screen sometimes. Other than those complaints, I would highly suggest.
cleaned_review: Total War: Shogun 2 is a game of war, diplomacy and strategic realism that has been praised by many. It is not just a strategy game, but a strategic game where political intrigues, dynamic relations and economic development are a key factor.

Reviews:
上手之后会立马显得重复度略高，而且局外成长太花时间，要体验到完整的内容很费劲。

其次在上强度之后，游戏会从模拟建设瞬间转化成微操资源管理，人力和资源的极致运用才能让你拿下胜利，你说肉鸽？什么肉鸽？哪有肉鸽？建设？哪有建设？

这不算充足的随机性除了能让你升血压并不能让你的体验得到提升，毕竟这个游戏所有的肉鸽收益基本都是有滞后性的，鲜少有立即生效却对你收益巨大的情况出现，游戏本身也是比起解决问题更倾向于让问题防患于未然，可以说基本都处于一种今日受苦而明日享福的循环，而人往往并不待见延迟满足，这也是城市建造类游戏的通病，随机性则让这一点被增幅了许多，毕竟脸黑一下的话你的精心布局很可能要到游戏尾声才得以找到key牌启动。

在真正上手游戏的中后期，本作特色的“肉鸽”“建设”属性可以说是基本等于没有（甚至肉鸽方面可能是负作用？），冲着这两点来的颇有几分受骗的味道。高强度下的资源匮乏和时间赛跑让游戏的建设属性约等于无，时间全花在拼尽全力管理有效利用资源上，而肉鸽属性正反馈不足，且低难度通解太多、高难度拿不到最优解血压又太高，负反馈很强导致肉鸽的设计很抽象。

相对的，游戏耐玩、结构与内容完整，微创新也不少，上手简单易懂，游戏内有明确的阶段性目标，能让城建玩的少的玩家不至于迷失方向不知道该做什么，每一局的目标不一样一定程度上保持了新鲜感都是值得肯定的优点。

总的来说是值得一个好评的，入手推荐史低，另DLC风评远不如本体，慎入。 | Against the Storm focuses on the best part of a city builder which is the first hours when you are in the building phase.  Against the Storm plays out differently every time because the buildings you start with are always different.   It is a well optimized game, with constant choices of risk vs reward, and enjoyable when you figure out work-arounds for meeting necessary resources, through supply chain management.

What I appreciate about Against the Storm is that there is never is a point where it gets too complicated with too much too deal with at one time.  The equivalent of the "Boss battle" is challenging and rewarding.  Graphic and sound design are excellent.

I've played over 650 hours and still not sick of it, so there must be something to this video game.  

Support these devs.  Eremite Games is a Polish developer consisting of six, and they really have created a real gem of a game, and they have been actively improving and polishing the game for more than a year after the day 1 release. | I genuinely started off liking Against the Storm, but the further you get into the difficulties the more tedious it gets, with additional negative modifiers and additional hoops to jump through to complete the session. Each seal completion really incentivizes you to play the next difficulty to get enough shards to complete the next seal to follow the metaplot, and lower difficulties may not get you the number of seals you need in time - additionally, the further out you go, the higher the minimum difficulty of the embarkment is, pushing the player to embark on those higher difficulty options. Why progress the seals other than metaplot? So you get more resources for the Citadel metaprogression. Which does things like add resources to your starting caravan so you can actually build some production buildings at the start, or adding a production building that let you make many key items - poorly, at high cost, but beneficial for the build chains so you are not fully reliant on RNG to get a building to complete the chain, or even adding bonuses to each race in your settlement like showing you where the first set of fields is where you can build a farm the first time you recruit a Human, so you don't have to spend half the session opening the wrong glades and never getting the constant food production that would provide. 

Except like many modern roguelite hybrids, this metaprogression is poorly balanced, and time consuming, which makes it feel like busywork rather than enjoyable on its own. It makes the higher difficulties less tedious to tackle (especially with some of the more helpful bonuses), but it just feels like an absolute chore to get through. Speaking of chores, they just add more chores without opening meaningful doors and mechanics past Veteran in terms of the difficulty options. The first three difficulties add mechanics each jump - after Veteran comes Viceroy, which is the same thing as Veteran with new forbidden and dangerous glade events to threaten your settlement and that the forest is more hostile by a multiplier of x3 instead of x2, but they don't do anything "new" really, they are just more of what you have seen before on earlier difficulties, and they just cost a ton of resources that you may not have been able to produce unless you have enough bonuses from the metaprogression tree and otherwise they apply so many negative benefits your game may actually end, such as the Stormbird which as far as I can tell by searching across the internet, people have been complaining is poorly balanced even with a good settlement for years. I don't just mean negatively either - the Stormbird applies an infinite storm effect, locking you to a year until you finish it (which you could delay), which is abusable in its own right if you were lucky enough to find it early. The Stormbird is just absurdly out of band in both directions and I cannot understand the intent of including it compared to every other event. I suppose that its very existence changes the logic pattern of whether you should open forbidden glades at all, but the higher difficulties disincentivize the opening of small glades due to hostility modifiers, so that just leaves dangerous glades if you do not want to starve but want to ensure a manageable event. What a forcible winnowing of the meta - it creates a very rote playstyle even though the apparent point of RNG building choice to create more unstable, dynamic push-and-pull gameplay. 

By the way, the tree also has a level attached - as you go through various sessions you get XP, when you level up you unlock new buildings and cornerstones (buffs) to show up in the game. THIS metaprogression mechanic is where the actual doors are opened for new build orders. Except its just as slow as the tree since its a blocker on the tree - without those later buildings and cornerstones, the game is not necessarily giving you the tools to win on higher difficulties. The amount of XP seems really low as well no matter the difficulty and even with completing various achievement challenges, which just exacerbates the issue.

I assume the decision not to bind those buildings and cornerstones to the higher difficulties and instead to a metaprogression level was so that you can use them on the lower difficulties and practice various build chains, but without overwhelming people when they start to play, and because of the complexity of creating a system that could both leave them default on the higher difficulties and then unlock them for use on the lower one once you cleared the higher one. Though perhaps they could have used their training missions for this. In all honesty the buildings beyond the first few levels matter less than the cornerstones, but they both add to how obnoxious the metaprogression system is - even if it is justified ludonarratively. 

In positives, I genuinely like the give and take between blight and production starting with the Veteran difficulty. I enjoy the season model and how each session naturally pushes you to modify your build chain on the fly or attempt to produce enough of your current resources to trade for the things you need to complete the Orders. I enjoy the fact that a session can take no more than one hour or maybe two at the higher speeds and therefore allows a bite-sized city building experience. I genuinely did get 30 hours out of it so I would say I got my money's worth, and I may play some more now and again, but anything that sufficiently annoys me more than it captivates me gets a negative review especially when the causes will not be immediately apparent to the player. | Let me preface this by saying that the game is very well made and I understand why so many people love it. I am not refunding it for any notable flaws.

For me specifically, when I play this type of game I want to dig in and work on one continuous settlement and make it grow over time, eventually getting to a point where I have this massive city that basically runs itself, giving me a primal sense of satisfaction that doesn't need to be felt again for roughly two years. But this game is a rogue-lite with some aspects of a mobile game, where you constantly restart a 'run', so to speak, unlocking stuff to make things more interesting for the next one. And though well-crafted, it's just not the kind of thing I'm looking for in a city-builder. | 与其说是城市营造或者基地建设，更像是有限资源管理游戏，不符合我的兴趣

Reviews:
Goodness the graphics are ugly in this game but somehow charming . Has Raven so I can't complain | Mortal Kombat but with DC characters, however this game is excellent. I remember playing it as a young stupid kid on the Xbox 360, and replaying it feels so nice. The graphics has held up as well imo, and everything else is great. The characters, the storyline, the fighting and such is easy to grasp and learn. I recommend playing with a controller then PC but up to you of course! I also got Injustice 2 and it's also awesome, I prefer this one I think but I like that the 2nd one added more characters, wish they had Batgirl, Zatanna, and Killer Frost though. Sucks they don't, but anyway I recommend this yet again, it's nicely done. And I hate the joker design from Injustice 2 lol, he's an edge lord now. it's terrible, this design is much much better LMAO | its a really fun game until you see a deathstroke player who keeps spamming sword flip and quick fire and starts teabagging to show this game's netcode is terrible or maybe you just suck at this game for me its both of them | É legal ver os heróis lutando. Quando joguei estava com controle que não possuía o R1 e R2, quando mudei de controle o jogo ficou super fácil, ai zerei com o superman que faltava. | 作为游戏没得说，确实是好游戏，尽管漫画宇宙的角色战力差别普遍比较大，但还是用超人药这种设定硬圆，毕竟本身就是图一爽快刺激的格斗游戏斗兽世界观，那么严肃干嘛
但偏偏就是有一群梗小鬼还真就严肃上了，就相中了不义宇宙讨论的那点黑暗呐  人性呐，就到粉丝圈子里乱刷来恶心主宇宙了，是不是看到点超英解构就走不动道了？
但小鬼讨厌不代表作品不行，对于一个超英主题的格斗游戏，众多场景互动使玩家很有dc世界沉浸感，也不会像街头格斗那样出戏，当然，战力差距导致出戏对于格斗游戏那肯定是不可避免的
脸模都比较一般，但毕竟是老游戏了，也不必苛责，不过演出效果也确实不如隔壁亲儿子mk
剧情选择了带来一个模板正联和不义宇宙区分开，我觉得这是真的很棒的设计，能同时照顾到不同侧的粉丝，是比二代的剧情设计强的点

Blood Rage ist ein sehr feines Spiel :)  Bei der Umsetzung hätte ich mir mehr Brettspielfeeling gewünscht. | Love the Board Game but the Interface made me just want to play this in person. If you dont have a group of friends that like this game I would recommend it however other than that Just play the game in person | The game is great. Yes there are some bugs, but if you love the board game and play the digital version enough, you know how to avoid triggering them. I think the multiplayer server is down but if you just wanna comp stomp, its way fun. I play against 4 AI on the hardest difficulty and it satisfies my bloodlust. | Yes. A fine digital adaptation of a real boardgame.
Entretenido para echarle un par de tardes. En 10 horas puedes hacer el 100% de los logros, por 2€ no está ni tan mal. | challenging but fair.
cleaned_review: Entretenido para echarle un par de tardes. En 10 horas puede hacer el 100% de los logros, por 2€ no está ni tan mal. | challenging but fair.

Reviews:
I've loved this game for years, however i cannot recommend it, considering the state of the studio and how they manage the game and their team. They prioritize quantity over quality, money over anything else, trying to pay as little as possible to their employees and not crediting free work put into the game. 
i recommend to watch this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ouSWPM4jfUY

Pixel Sprout games; Artists, programmers, writers, translators and everyone else deserves to be paid properly. they are the only reason this game is what it is. They deserve better and you should be fucking ashamed | I cannot recommend this game, at all. 

I loved this game, I bought it for friends (19 people, I have bought this game for 19 people). It was SDV but fantasy and I loved it, but it really isn't possible for me to recommend this game anymore. I've played this since it was Early Access. I have 380 hours in this game, almost all the achievements. 

The team has consistently dropped the ball with various things:
- no credits for any of the creators, artists, coders, etc
- nintendo switch issues
- issues with the discord and questions not being answered
- people not receiving codes
- constant dlc release
- so many bugs, even on PC (I have lost saves at times)
- awful translations for different languages (with unpaid work)

This could've been something new, something better. And it isn't. The community was horribly failed. Do better, please. Hire more community managers or communicate better. It's unacceptable the amount of times people have brought up in the discord not receiving codes or entirely being ignored. The team does NOT communicate with the player base at all. The switch version was released entirely broken. Nintendo told customers to contact Pixel Sprout for refunds and I saw multiple times that the people asking about that and the refunds were ignored. Only now are they trying to backtrack after all the backlash. I get it that it can cause issues, but communication has been HORRIBLE. At most, they announce "we know it's broken, and we don't know when it'll be fixed, oopsie". The radio silence for other players has been disheartening to see. 

The translators at first were volunteers. Then the dev team cut them off and used some stupid AI translation. Then they had people "volunteer" to fix their machine translation. 

Employees were also not paid fairly. People were paid well below minimum wage. Everything is out there, just look into it. There's multiple posts from former employees, google documents, tweets-- all have evidence and proof.

People were banned for bringing up concerns in the discord or for speaking up about various issues. I might get banned myself for posting this review. It's unacceptable behavior. Stop being defensive and own up to mistakes. 

As for the actual game? It's cute, the pixel graphics are nice (some of them are wonky). The story is okay. The immersion is pretty good, but it drops the ball in some other areas, like relationships and marriage. NPCs are unique, there's plenty of different characters for everyone. Furniture is still not able to be turned for the majority of things. The story needs to have a lot of retcon or fixing, I think. So far? It's you grind, you go to a elf city, you talk to a dragon. You go to a demon city, then you either give stuff to a dragon or fight it, and then there's nothing after. It's a very boring story in places and very grindy. The seasonal enemies are fun. DLCs are done right only for the sole fact that they're cosmetic only and don't really do much for gameplay itself.

Look into what you're purchasing first. I'm highly disappointed with the team and the way they have behaved as well as the way they have treated the community. I'm not buying any Pixel Sprout games ever again and I'm telling all of my friends, family, even strangers, to do the same. 

Highly recommend Fields of Mistria, Stardew Valley, various other games in that vein as opposed to Sun Haven. I'm sure there are going to be more fantasy stardew-esque games from better developers and better company. | De que adianta ser um jogo bonito se mal pagam os artistas e não dão crédito nenhum pra eles? De que adianta ter um milhão de coisas e um milhão de dlcs se bugs do jogo base nunca foram resolvidos? Além disso os devs não tem nenhum relacionamento com as pessoas que jogam, só dão as caras pra banir quem critica alguma coisa | ゲームは面白いが日本語翻訳が酷い。
また開発元は携わったスタッフをクレジットに載せない、最低賃金も支払わない等暴挙を行っていると告発されている。
従業員を大切にしない企業は淘汰されるべき。 | ゲーム自体は良いゲームです。
ですが開発者にとにかく問題があり、このゲームを購入したことを後悔しています。
買った当時は「神ゲーキタコレ！アプデで翻訳がもう少し良くなりますように…」とか思っていたのに本当残念です。

Reviews:
Любитель тактических RPG определенно стоит оценить данный проект. Сам проиграл не малое количество времени по пиратке, но решил поддержать разработчика и приобрел игру. Обязательно вернусь еще в игру, но жду обновления и нужное настроение. 
Обновления выходят, за что респект разработчику и желаю ему успехов!!!
Игру рекомендую | Fun game with lots of potential. If dev continues to add more combat and magic skills, this could compete with ToME, | I don't recommend this quite yet.

Needs a more fleshed out character creator and magic added before I'd recommend buying. | Me está gustando mucho, tanto que creo que voy a dejar de jugarlo para retomarlo cuando esté completo sin quemarlo, cosa que pasa con los early acces. 

Es un roguelike tradicional de mundo abierto con agradables gráficos y, en general, presenta la información en pantalla de un modo claro. Tiene un sistema de habilidades amplio que evoluciona un poco a lo Skyrim. Me recuerda a Stoneshard pero con más elementos de fantasía tradicional. Tiene un sistema de progresión lento pero bien pensado, muy inmersivo. Parece más bien pensado para jugarlo con posibilidad de guardar y recargar la partida si te matan, en un punto no muy avanzado del juego incluso se hacen referencias a que estás dominando el tiempo al volver de la muerte una y otra vez. Es demasiado tentador no usar el modo permadeath aunque no se juega igual sabiendo que la muerte no penaliza. 

Sobre la partida que estoy jugando. He elegido la clase caballero, uso principalmente espada, ya he aprendido algunos hechizos que sirven para encantar el equipamiento aunque me faltan ingredientes para usar los hechizos. No parece que haya magia activa, de lanzar bolas de fuego, etc. He tenido la suerte de que la granja cercana al pueblo de inicio produce huevos de avestruz, que se regeneran cada poco tiempo, como también se regenera el dinero de los comerciantes. Cada visita a la granja me reporta 20 huevos de media, que se venden a 6 piezas de oro, así que tengo una fuente modesta pero inagotable de ingresos y comida. Además estoy subiendo mi nivel de cocina muy rápido. Como en todo buen roguelike, si algo es susceptible de exploit entonces es lícito explotarlo hasta el infinito para obtener una ventaja, no estoy alterando las reglas que están ahí puestas.

Se me olvidaba comentarlo, puedes robar impunemente.

Todavía no he avanzado mucho en alquimia, me curo usando comida, que te da X turnos de potenciación a la curación, así que en enfrentamientos duros lo que hago es pegar al malo, cuando estoy bajo de vida como algo y empiezo a correr en círculos para que vaya subiendo la vida con el enemigo pegado a mis talones. Es eficaz pero muy ridículo.

No me quiero extender más, un juego muy divertido, un roguelike accesible pero exigente para los que estamos descubriendo este mundillo y todavía juegos como Caves of Qud o ToME se nos hacen un poco abstrusos. A mis +40 años ya muchos juegos del mercado me aburren, las historias me parecen una chorrada (sí, las de Kojima también, no es Coppola) y todo me da una sensación de que ya lo he visto antes, y me encuentro a mí mismo atraído como una polilla a la luz hacia los roguelike más tradicionales, es curioso. 
 | Потенциал имеется, уже контента неплохое количество. Роадмап действительно впечатляет, поэтому ждём
cleaned_review: I love it. It's a roguelike of the world, open with nice graphics and, in general, presents information in a clear pane. It has a system of broad abilities that evolve a bit to Skyrim. I remember Stoneshard but with more elements of traditional fantasy. It has a system of progressing slow but well thought out, very inmersivo. It seems more well thought out to play it with

Reviews:
Почему Dune: Spice Wars заработала Shiro Games существенно меньше денег, чем Northgard или хотя бы Wartales?

Думаю, дело в следующем:

1. Сложнее въехать (чем в другие работы Shiro). Надо провести хотя бы часов 5-6. И сходу непонятны не только мелкие нюансы, а целые механики.

2. Это не римейк той самой Dune 2. Нет танков, ракетниц, выдуманных Ордосов и много чего ещё. Так уж получилось, что совершенно неканоническая разработка Westwood для многих игроков является первоисточником.

3. Это не особо похоже на Northgard. Вернее, совсем непохоже.

4. Это не RTS, а стратегия 4X. Может быть не такая навороченная как некоторые представители жанра. Но тут точно не работает никакой раш и типовые для RTS подходы.

А теперь то же самое, но с точки зрения плюсов:

1. Что такое 5-6 часов для 4X? Я в своё время в Civ5 въезжал дольше, а в Stellaris окончательно понял как играть через 30 часов. 5-6 часов - просто идеальное время для понимания стратегии такого типа.

2. Shiro гораздо бережнее поработали с книгами. И эта работа с ограничениями заставила их выверять подходы и особенности до мелочей.

3. Если честно, я Spice Wars полгода боялся запускать. Так как думал, что это рескин Northgard с некоторыми наворотами. Ура, это не он!

4. Кому-то вообще нужна была бы Dune 3000? Серьёзно? Жанр устарел ещё в начале 00-х.

А ещё! Здесь редко бывает больше 10-12 юнитов под контролем - и это заставляет включать голову. Общая медлительность позволяет воевать на 2, а иногда даже на 3 фронта. Есть активная пауза (для соло-игры). Дерево развития выверено до мелочей. Стороны сильно отличаются по фишкам. Графика, стиль и вообще UI в целом - идеал.

Короче, отличная игра. Одна из лучших стратегий, в которые я играл за последнее время. | Interesting to begin with.  The game plateaus very quickly though. Very little replayable value for me.  After a couple of hours it gets tedious.  Boring.  I regret buying this game. | The novel Dune was written during the Cold War, and this game has that aura.

Do not expect a standard RTS. This is a game about statecraft, about cold wars, about the balance of power, about paranoia. Warfare is a continuation of policy by other means- often an inevitable one, but more pursued to deny the enemy victory than to seize it. It's more about medieval-style raids & chevauchées than massive campaigns. The Landsraad and intelligence systems are brilliant. Expect assassinations to be a more common threat than sieges of enemy capitals are.

As an adaptation of the novel within the confines of a Civ-style game, it's excellent. The great dangers of Arrakis, the thirst & the worms, are of both strategic & tactical importance- by which I mean they will destroy your entire army if you slip up. So many of the little details of the world are here as well, down to the Fremen donkeys. The factions from the book are invoked wonderfully in gameplay too- the honor and "honor" of the Atreides, the drugged-up thuggery of the Harkonnen troops, the vicious, vampiric fanaticism of the Fremen, the Corrinos lurking aside, playing one House against another until they can throw down a fortress from orbit and seize the planet for themselves. The additional factions are flavorful too.

I'd recommend this game in particular to those who love the book & its cynical philosophy, and to those who like the idea of games like Civ but want something leaner, quicker, & smarter. 

Note that God created the single-player mode to train for the multiplayer mode. This review has assumed that it's the latter you'll be getting the game for. | Feels great. The environment is very dangerous but fair. Politics works, which is impressive for this kind of game. The factions have good differentiation- Harkonnens oppress their people and throw away their own people to feed the machine. Fremen move easily in the desert but they don't get to vote in politics. Atreides can be very effective politcally and can take villages peacefully. And whoever you are, there are the constant pressures of collecting the Spice. | Ce genre de jeux qui arrive à rendre simple une gestion complexe et multiple (économie, politique, militaire tactique et stratégique...)
Ayant découvert l'univers Dune depuis peu, je souhaitais trouver un jeu vidéo à la hauteur de celui-ci, me voilà tombé sur ce jeu réalisé par un studio français. Et c'est franchement une super bonne surprise, étant fan du genre, c'est vraiment du très bon boulot. La plupart des jeux de cette catégorie ont tendance à rapidement devenir des foutoirs incompréhensibles... Ici, c'est bien fait
Le jeu laisse vraiment la possibilité de gagner et de jouer comme on le souhaite, la faction qu'on veut également puisque pas mal de maisons sont jouables
Le côté aléatoire des évènements sont également pas mal pour assurer une bonne rejouabilité

Bref, je recommande
cleaned_review: Dune: Spice Wars is a lot more fun than Northgard or Wartales.

Reviews:
制作者的妈临死前想见他一面，制作者急不可耐放下传送门，上面显示需要等待10分钟

制作台做的装备有一半都是垃圾，困难难度下拿制作台装备打boss跟刮痧一样，什么你问正常的装备怎么搞，先去刷一千只怪挖一千个土，就有1%概率出了
把装备藏怪物掉落里尚可理解，藏你妈土里面，挖土概率出宝箱，宝箱里面再概率出装备，你妈可能活着，但是概率是0
更死妈的是把装备藏地图上随机位置刷新的房间里，然后房间里还概率出装备，做个破b装备全地图翻一遍，你是不是他妈脑子进屎了让玩家搁着当赛博苦力
打个破boss还要召唤物，召唤物里面还要一个1%概率掉落的稀有物品，然后被boss打死召唤物就白放得重新做一个

你说不去搞那些概率装备呢？你看看你那b制作台装备什么强度
困难难度接近满级，穿制作台装备吃boss两个射弹就秒杀，吃两个加伤食物，拿制作台武器，一个boss10分钟起步，逼着你去搞那些概率武器，概率入脑了真就

跑个破图跑半小时都走不到半圈，路上全是些垃圾怪和材料，为了找隐藏房而找的探图模式，还有你那死了妈一样的10分钟传送门放置时间

对于泰拉瑞亚的拙劣模仿者 | 建议加一个衣服皮肤栏位，然后更新更多好看的衣服，这样我觉得会吸引更多人来玩。穿着好看衣服的同时，不会影响本身的护甲和属性。 | This is a great game! It's like a top-down Terraria. Build your base, collect materials, find and upgrade gear and tackle all the bosses. The music is great and the story is pretty good. | 这游戏前期确实玩着上头，但是仅限前期，当你玩到后期打到新三泰坦的时候，你就会发现这游戏为了留住玩家做了什么恶心的事情，巨大的世界，频繁无意义的跑图，三块小宝石，找不到就打不了BOSS，不是哥们，我玩游戏还是游戏玩我，我第一次打游戏打到出现疲惫无力的感觉，只能说制作组在恶心玩家这上面是有一手的。 | [i]Core Keeper[/i] initially impresses, but then the diminishing returns reduce the fun factor.

I loved what I saw in Early Access. I decided that this game would be best played with friends once it hit 1.0, so I put it down for Future Me, and Future Us, to experience together.

Early on, it was great. We’re all veterans of [i]Terraria[/i]. In particular, I enjoyed the automation of gathering nodes and sending them along back to base.

But once you crack that initial outer wall open, oh boy, does it get grindy right quick.

You need ten whatsits to create the thingamajig that lets you scan for the boss. Fine, OK. But then you’re going to need 10 whozsamutsises to create the next boss scanning item, unless you want to explore the entirely-too-big map to find the boss on your own. So just adjust your playstyle and preferences accordingly, because you, son, are going to grind, and grind, and grind if you want to participate in this world.

I wasn’t having fun. I felt bad that I recommended this game to my friend group, and when I floated the idea that maybe we should move on to something less grindy, they basically said, “Oh, yeah, absolutely. We were only playing this because we thought you were really into it.” Admittedly, I was. At first.

The map needs to be smaller if this game is going for a boss-rush gameplay model. The grind needs to be lessened if you want people with lives and jobs to be interested. There’s a lot to love about the first handful of hours played, but it’s an absolute fumble after that point. Quite the disappointment.

我认为我去选择玩这个种族就是想体验这个种族独特的科技与魔法，而不是换皮肤体验重复的大家共享的魔法池。但不管是最近要出的文明还是这个游戏都把这些体验拆分开来，文明可选，外观可选，科技和魔法都可选，看似更自由了，但想看另一个魔法另一个种族的特性的这种新开存档的激情却减少了，总而言之就是没意思了，没有独特的种族游玩流程那还有什么意思呢？ | The Game itself is a very good tactical turn based game. It combines a campaign map with turn based battles. You can create your own civilization with its ruler and heroes, and play as the fantasy (or steam-punk) civilization you always wanted.

But I have some bigger issues with this game:

First off, since the last big update, the game has a tendency to crash on the campaign map. Which is really annoying, but dealbreaker for me is, that it also corrupts saves, so you cannot continue where it crashed. Especially annoying when you just fought a big battle and then lose all your progress.

Second is, that yes - you can create different civs - but in the end, they all play very similar. You always want to rush your city cap and just build as many armies as possible. Build wide, claim as much territory as possible. That's the strategy. The only difference is how your units look and what tomes you unlock. To be fair, some of the final tomes are very unique, but it takes a very long time till you get there and most of the game is already over by that point.

Third, the campaign map itself. You notice it is randomly generated. It's a combination of biomes with some features in it and some randomly placed ancient wonders. Every map looks similar. Sometimes it has more forest and sometimes more sand, but in the end, there are no "unique" landmarks or sights. After a few games, you have seen everything. Which would be okay, but one of the key points of this game is to go out and explore the map... which is just not interesting.

 | This game destroys EVERYTHING that you want to do in real life for the next 20+ hours the moment you start it.
So beware, if you are not on vacation, don't even attempt to LOOK at the "Play" button.

10/10

Would create 30 more factions with different traits anytime again.

Please, let me go. | Отличная игра, лучше взять ее чем отдать 7к за базовую цивилизацию 7.:) | It's a good game. Early game is a blast. Middle game is so so. End game is boring.

I have the same problem with this game as with Total War series -- late game battles are boring and tedious, zero fun. In this particular example, auto combat is very well executed: AI actually plays the battle so no surprising results happen. But then, I never see those fancy hero skills which I choose with such care.

I recomend this for a few hours, 'till the boredom comes.

Reviews:
When I first saw this game I thought it looked ridiculous, a pointless waste of time. Nothing about it sounded fun. But then I watched a video of someone playing it on YouTube and thought it looked much more fun than the promotional videos had shown. So I gave it a try and OMG, I totally enjoyed this game. It has no right to be as fun as it is. I tend to be a completionist and this game helped scratch that itch. The best part is that I'm a huge fan of Castlevania so that DLC was just the greatest thing I never knew I needed. Seriously, for me the Castlevania DLC made the game at least 10x more fun.

My only complaint would be it's kind of a one and done for me. Once everything is collected I don't feel a need to play it. Loved playing it that first time around though, collecting all the things, unlocking all the stuff, it was fantastic. I'd have to do a complete fresh install to relock everything to make unlocking it again enjoyable. But still, it was the best 190+ hours of my recent gaming life :D | A lot of people like it but I honestly found it kind of boring. Just wander around automatically shooting stuff until you get overwhelmed, then repeat. It's fine but wasn't my kind of game. | It's a fun game where you survive 30 minutes at a time (15 with hurry mode or endless when unlocked) as hordes of enemies crowd your screen and you get ever increasingly ridiculous weapons. A good number of hours out of it, especially for the price point. There's a lot of characters, different weapons, evolutions, secrets, stages etc. Sometimes things get so ridiculous that you can't even see what's going on anymore, but it's all part of the charm of the game.

I don't really have any critiques, because it does what it sets out to very well. I will say though that the game is considerably easier than I expected it was going to be going in. | Literalmente el juego del vicio a su máximo esplendor, el trailer habla por si solo, vas a dejar tu vida jugando a este juego para conseguir todos los desbloqueables y probar todas las combinaciones o personajes posibles.

El contenido que obtienes de juego por lo que pagas es totalmente justo, ya poseo todos los DLC hasta la fecha y realmente cada uno suma una cantidad de contenido absurdo que da para aun mas horas de juego.

Además, como fan de la saga Castlevania es muy divertido ir notando cada una de las referencias que guarda este juego y cuando añadieron el DLC de Castlevania, literalmente explote.
 | This game has the best ratio between the amount of fun you'll have with the fewest amount of buttons. I've never played anything this deep with literally just WSAD and Space. Also, 5€ full price for this? What a bargain. I get that it's a simple game, but come on. Give yourselves some credit, devs. And thanks for the full ultrawide support, although I would prefer a third option to solid and transparent black bars, which would be no black bars, but that's a massive nitpick.

EDIT: Ooooooh! That's how they make money! They have DLCs, so the whole game is actually 20€ if you want everything. That makes way more sense. Still too cheap though, because from what I've tried from the DLCs so far, they are very good and definitely worth the asking price.

But still, it was the best 190+ hours of my recent gaming life :D
